description: We asked you to tell us about the time you crossed from one side of the debate to the other
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: We asked you to tell us about the time you crossed from one side of the debate to the other
og_fields.og:title: 'My partner convinced me of the facts': readers on changing their opinion on climate change
text:
I first thought it was fake as I used to watch Fox News with my family. In 2015 I met my partner Stephen who knew that the facts of climate change couldn’t be ignored. He took it upon himself to try to convince me. We started watching documentaries on the subject on Netflix. The first documentary that caught my attention was Cowspiracy directed by Kip Andersen and Keegan Kuhn. This documentary really hit home and I even wrote an essay on it. Then came What the Health by the same directors. After we watched the movie Stephen and I turned to an all plant-based diet. We have our ups and downs on staying true to our new lifestyle change, but we always keep in mind that for every burger we don’t eat that is 660 gallons of water that we are saving for others in need. I was lucky enough that Stephen took the time and saw that if I could see the issues I would see that the facts are true.
As a graduate student in the early 2000s, I did not really have an opinion on the matter but the debate raised my curiosity. So when some of the prominent sceptical websites made claims about some scientific papers, I searched for the papers online and checked for myself. It soon became quite obvious that the sceptic claims made no sense whatsoever. So I became politically active and I’ve now been active in the Finnish Green party for 10 years. 
Climate change seemed like a questionable thing to me at first and now it’s not. What made me change my mind is several news articles and blogs that I’ve read up on the internet as well as visits to museums and exhibitions. It was informative and introduced aspects such as rising temperatures, rising seas, extreme weather events and risks that we as a community face. I believe it will help people understand how serious the situation is and I would like to encourage the community to visit museums and learn about climate change. Given everything I have been told, my belief in climate change has gone from weak to very strong even if I still have many questions. After learning about how bad this can really get, it not only changed whether or not I believed in it, but also made me worry more and more. I now understand that I must try to do things that benefit the environment but at the same time I must also understand that I can’t save the world.
I was a teenager when President Ronald Reagan reassured us that global warming was all part of a natural, cyclical process - not dangerous and not caused by humans. Being a young, naive Republican, I believed him. When Al Gore’s documentary An inconvenient Truth came out in theatres, I would never have considered going to see it if I hadn’t become angry about Bush’s decision to invade Iraq and cynical about the Republicans’ lip service to Christian values. The movie was an eye-opener to say the least. Now I am a Green Party member, try to live a zero waste life, I’m nearly vegan and read up on climate change issues in the news on a regular basis. I agree 100% with Pope Francis’ encyclical on the environment that fighting climate change is a moral imperative for social justice and that it is a grave sin to be tyrants rather than stewards of the earth. 
I believe that the climate is changing, but I now think that the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change’s view on the importance of CO2 is significantly overstated. I assumed that mainstream science was right and agree that burning fossil fuels is generally harmful and should be reduced if possible. However, after researching more about the factors effecting our climate I am of the opinion that other factors are more important than the IPCC stated factors. The sun and solar magnetic flux, plus the ocean currents are much more significant than stated by some scientist and the press. I also see significant data manipulation and misinformation (from both sides) so finding good independent sources of information is hard. I check published ‘hard data’ against obvious proxy data to see if it agrees, and too often it doesn’t. I think climate science has become political (understandable given the consequences) which means normal scientific debate is not happening as it should. 
I used to think climate change was a serious problem but now I think it has been overblown. As a research physicist I looked at research first hand and came to the conclusion that the modelling of climate is not particularly good. Catastrophic predictions are silly. Global warming is real but not as serious as portrayed in the press. The probable total effect on the climate due to people is nothing to worry about compared to other, far more urgent ecological or environmental concerns, such as land management, ocean management, invasive species etc. Also, regardless of the actual reality of catastrophic global warming the actual actions taken have been ridiculous, futile, expensive and have had no impact on CO2 production in any meaningful way. If predictions made in the 90s had been true, the only solution was to use the already developed, reliable, cheap nuclear power and to get India, China and African countries using it. Instead people are burning fuel.

The most common and significant GHG is actually water vapour NOT Co2
BQEND
You are correct that water vapour is the dominant GHG, but without CO2, the Earth would not be warm enough to have a water vapour greenhouse effect in the first place.
Water vapour cannot drive climate change, because any excess water vapour simply precipitates and quickly falls back to Earth. The atmosphere can only hold more water vapour if something else causes the temperature to rise first. Adding extra CO2 to the atmosphere does precisely that. 
CO2 thus acts as the main "control knob" of the greenhouse effect, with the consequent water vapour feedback serving as an "amplifier".
By drawing attention to this water vapour feedback, you are not diminishing the importance of CO2 in the least - you are in fact merely highlighting just how sensitive the climate is to CO2.', u'recommendation_count': u'12', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526830215000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'any excess water vapour simply precipitates and quickly falls back to earth', u'effect': u'water vapour can not drive climate change'}, {u'cause': u'something else', u'effect': u'the temperature to rise first'}], u'author_id': u'15902664', u'in_reply_to': u'116012029', u'id': u'116027570', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Vlamingo', u'text': u'I am not disputing your right to say what you like here, Bob - merely pointing out that if we wish to properly inform ourselves, we must take care to go to the most reliable sources.

All I need to know is the climate in 1818 compared to the climate in 2018.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526693621000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'115977030', u'id': u'115979194', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'"As a geologists you should appreciate that we struggle to understand what the world was truly like in the past."
The best way of understanding the truth of what the world is and was like or what it is and was truly like, is through science. Science is hard work but the results in terms of understanding are worth are worth the effort.
You say that the statement that, " just as the present is the key to the past, the past is the key to the present", makes no sense.
Long-term patterns and short-term natural disasters reoccur through the course of history, and for that reason, we look to the present to see what happened in the past. Rivers erode and cut down into their bed particularly when flowing across bedrock which is undergoing uplift. This is seen by the incised meanders of the Brisbane river, a river also well known for its floods. These floods inundate lower areas adjacent to the river dropping sediment load as the flood abates. Thus the behaviour of the river in the present explains the rich riverside soils deposited in the past and the very old incised course of the river.
Not all processes have taken place in recent historical time. Before the current global warming that phenomena had not occurred for 9,000 years. We can use our understanding of the global warming that occurred from 19,000 to 9,000 years ago to understand what's going on with the current global warming. For each such victory nature takes its revenge on us. Each victory, it is true, in the first place brings about the results we expected, but in the second and third places it has quite different, unforeseen effects which only too often cancel out the first…. Thus at every step we are reminded that we by no means rule over nature like a conqueror over a foreign people, like someone standing outside nature—but that we, with flesh, blood, and brain, belong to nature, and exist in its midst, and that all our mastery of it consists in the fact that we have the advantage over all other creatures of being able to learn its laws and apply them correctly.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526686798000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14911053', u'id': u'115978167', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'LocknessMunster', u'text': u'Deniers have been attempting to link the word 'denier' to the Holocaust for decades now.It's just another of their filthy tricks to attempt to stifle discussion about Climate Change. It is also interesting that more than a few legal firms (overseas) are telling their clients that they had better brush on their corporate footwork concerning climate change. Otherwise they will be "challenged" on several fronts. By the corporate regulators for bad business practices inasmuch as they haven't factored in CC: by their shareholders in Class Actions for fairly much the same reasons and so on.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526685494000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'they are a risk outside the insurance company guidelines', u'effect': u"that do n't will face astronomical increases or the threat of refusing to supply service"}], u'author_id': u'12016458', u'in_reply_to': u'115941942', u'id': u'115977944', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, ...]
description: Threat is not a possible future one but one endangering Australia now, parliament told
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Threat is not a possible future one but one endangering Australia now, parliament told
og_fields.og:title: Climate change an 'existential security risk' to Australia, Senate inquiry says
text:
Climate change is a “current and existential national security risk” to Australia, a Senate inquiry has told parliament, one that could inflame regional conflicts over food, water and land, and even imperil life on Earth.
The Senate committee inquiry into the implications of climate change for Australia’s national security recommended an increase in foreign aid to be dedicated to climate change mitigation and adaptation in the region, as well as a government white paper on climate security, Department of Defence emissions targets and a dedicated climate security post within the Department of Home Affairs.
The inquiry, which released its report on Thursday afternoon, heard that the security risk of climate change was not a possible future threat but one that endangers Australia and its region now. The Asia-Pacific was the region “most vulnerable” to the security and humanitarian impacts of climate change, the committee heard, and faced an “existential threat”.
An existential threat was defined as “one that threatens the premature extinction of Earth-originating intelligent life or the permanent and drastic destruction of its potential for desirable future development”.
Sign up to receive the top stories in Australia every day at noon
The committee report said climate change threatened Australians’ health, and the viability of communities, businesses and the economy. Climate change was heightening the severity of natural hazards, increasing the spread of infectious diseases and increasing water insecurity, and threatening agriculture.
Sherri Goodman, a former US deputy undersecretary of defence in the Clinton administration and founder of the CNA Military Advisory Board, told the committee climate change was a “threat multiplier”, exacerbating existing conflicts over water and other resources, and that it posed “a direct threat to the national security of Australia”.
“The problem also is not a distant one in the future but it’s now. We are experiencing this in regular sunny-day flooding at military bases in the United States and in changes in the Arctic, forcing the first wave of displaced persons from villages in the Arctic.”
The Climate Council told the committee climate change was “already contributing to increases in the forced migration of people within and between nations, as well as playing a role in heightening social and political tensions, flowing onto conflict and violence”.
The Australian government has recognised the security implications posed by climate change. Its seventh national communication on climate change to the United Nations in December highlighted that Australia was “already experiencing the impacts of a changing climate, particularly changes associated with increases in temperature, the frequency and intensity of extreme heat events, extreme fire weather and drought”.
It noted “communities in the Torres Strait are already being impacted by rising sea levels and many of the region’s coral reefs have been severely impacted by increased sea surface temperatures”.
And the Department of Defence agreed climate change had the potential to worsen existing conflicts.
“When climate impacts are combined with ethnic or other social grievances, they can contribute to increased migration, internal instability or intrastate insurgencies, often over greater competition for natural resources. These developments may foster terrorism or cross-border conflict.”
The Senate committee heard that acute climate disruption – in particular long-running and severe droughts – exacerbated conflicts in Mali and Syria, contributing to the destabilisation of fragile states.
In Australia’s region, the Australian Council for International Development said: “For Pacific nations such as Tuvalu, Kiribati and Micronesia, climate change is already a genuine existential threat with the capacity to diminish their livelihoods and even erase their states’ territorial footprints.”
The Senate committee noted Australia does not have an overarching climate security strategy. 
Research Director for Breakthrough National Centre for Climate Restoration David Spratt said there was a disconnect between the evidence presented to the inquiry and the recommendations that emerged from it.
“Existential risk management requires brutally honest articulation of the risks, opportunities and the response time frame. At the moment we are knowingly locking in an existential disaster without being prepared to articulate that fact … at least this Senate inquiry report is significant for having broken the ice, but it should be so much more.”
Greens Senator Peter Whish-Wilson said the defence personnel who appeared before the committee “engaged deeply with climate change science and were in no doubt that a warming world is a more dangerous world”.
“What this inquiry has brought home to me is that when people choose to engage with the climate science, without any partisan or ideological blinkers, they quickly understand the seriousness of the challenge and decide to act. We have seen that the Australian Defence Force is changing how it does things because it is taking climate change seriously, but we have a government that is doing nothing to reduce emissions to actually reduce the threat of climate change itself.”

Those birds and rodents had never seen cats and did not suspect they were predators.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527013639000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11577802', u'in_reply_to': u'116080792', u'id': u'116108219', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'quatsch', u'text': u'People don't need gardens to assist. i live on the 6th floor in a city centre, but have a large terrace. Cats have killed off birds...
BQEND
"Despite the large numbers of birds killed by cats in gardens, there is no clear scientific evidence that such mortality is causing bird populations to decline. This may be surprising, but many millions of birds die naturally every year, mainly through starvation, disease or other forms of predation. There is evidence that cats tend to take weak or sickly birds...It is likely that most of the birds killed by cats would have died anyway from other causes before the next breeding season, so cats are unlikely to have a major impact on populations...Those bird species which have undergone the most serious population declines in the UK (such as skylarks, tree sparrows and corn buntings) rarely encounter cats, so cats cannot be causing their declines"
Source: The RSPB (who have every reason to want to protect birds and vilify cats)https://www.rspb.org.uk/birds-and-wildlife/advice/gardening-for-wildlife/animal-deterrents/cats-and-garden-birds/are-cats-causing-bird-declines/', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526972289000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'such mortality', u'effect': u'bird populations to decline'}, {u'cause': u'cats', u'effect': None}], u'author_id': u'13292229', u'in_reply_to': u'116076809', u'id': u'116080792', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonathanHughes', u'text': u'Invasive species cannot be contained everywhere that is certainly true (imagine trying to ridmost od the world of rats) but where it can be done (primarily islands where invasive species are most dangerous) it should be.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526969359000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12031469', u'in_reply_to': u'116076809', u'id': u'116080059', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'heavensabuv', u'text': u'Brilliant initiative. It isn't the town building that is the problem, it is the chronic land mismanagement from farmers who destroy meadows, rip up trees and hedgerows, drain ponds, let cattle and sheep destroy streams and rivers, and who use massive amounts of insecticides and herbicides. That is who to blame for the destruction of countryside and wildlife, the farmers.
 So thank the housebuilders, all those new gardens are what is keeping birds and insects alive.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526938492000}, u'causal_relations': None, I take similar short trips every year and it was not long ago that I would have to clean the windshield of myriad bugs at the end of every day. For the past several years the amount of insects collected there is down significantly, I'd say 80%. I might go 2-3 days before I feel the need to clean the windshield.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526911203000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13574684', u'id': u'116060770', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'FloridaAuthor', u'text': u'BQSTART
richardjwilliams: Golf clubs are brilliant at conserving nature. ...
BQEND

aldebaranredstar ... electricity is not generated by pollution-free methods. Electricity is produced by various awful means that add to pollution, whereas, according to the article, cars are actually more efficient now and burn less fuel and emit less pollutants ...
BQEND
Yes. Some of us jokingly refer to "coal-powered cars" but I am forced to admit that, to a small degree, electric is better in terms of pollution — largely because it transfers the pollution to a belching smokestack somewhere remote. 
It's just inconvenient; I don't have to plug in my gasoline monster each night. It goes 'way more than a few hundred miles (and few electrics can get even that far). I can refuel it anywhere in ten minutes versus special battery-recharge places where I spend hours watching my ... watch. And it doesn't need a $10,000 battery replacement after a few years (that battery being, itself, a very nasty environmental problem).
Make me a me an electric that can be recharged in ten minutes once or twice a month at any of tens of thousands of stations around the country, that can go 300 or more miles on a charge, that doesn't cost as much as my house, and that doesn't need an expensive rebuild at 50,000 miles — and I'm all in.
Until then, I love the smell of NOX in the morning.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526908928000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'largely it transfers the pollution to a belching smokestack somewhere remote', u'effect': u'that to a small degree electric is better in terms of pollution \u2014'}], u'author_id': u'18227126', u'in_reply_to': u'116043685', u'id': u'116059090', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'tomcobbly1969', u'text': u'Substituting the 'Golf clubs' for farming of course....', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526908340000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18374959', u'in_reply_to': u'116057532', u'id': u'116058673', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'hermithouse', u'text': u'there are soo many cars it cant be good for any wildlife', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526932705000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17657970', u'in_reply_to': u'116050634', u'id': u'116072117', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Aslioch', u'text': u'BQSTART

How a lot of Trump (and Brexit) voters feel about now ...', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526907802000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18227126', u'in_reply_to': u'116052743', u'id': u'116058190', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'krnlgmp', u'text': u'On top of that is more complexity though I'm sure. For a start, free market thinking has lead to "consumer choice" being one of the few influences on the system that a regular person has. But many people are insulated from the negative effects of the products they buy; in a globalised world, there is no obvious connection between buying a sandwich in the supermarket and deforestation in Papua New Guinea. But the connection is there once you look at Palm Oil and the unsatisfactory "sustainable" palm oil certification used in the supply chain. So people's consumer choices actually don't fit people's own ethical standards.
Personally I'd love it if we just worked out how to run an economy that doesn't require producing increasingly more and more products that we don't really need.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526907667000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'free market thinking', u'effect': u'consumer choice'}], u'author_id': u'13472177', u'in_reply_to': u'116057702', u'id': u'116058085', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'hermithouse', u'text': u'stop building on every last inch of land every field round me is got planning permission on it no wonder we have flooding and no insects', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526930013000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17657970', u'id': u'116071003', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonathanHughes', u'text': u'I don't disagree with a lot of what you say. The incessant seeing of species that don't have an immediate obvious utility being viewed as pests is a huge problem (with the exception of invasive species which, very sadly, should be viewed as ecological pests)
I actually think increased urbanisation (which does probably disconnect people from the environment) is probably a good thing as it frees up space (I also have doubts that people were more environmentally friendly in the past - just less capable of destroying it!)
I also happen to agree that education is going to be key in tackling some of these issues but we are also going to have to take pretty drastic action against plastics, pesticides etc (As well as many other topics including some that aren't nice (wiping out invasive species sadly is going to be on that list)', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526929325000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12031469', u'in_reply_to': u'116070209', u'id': u'116070724', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Aslioch', u'text': u'it's almost impossible to wipe out insects Wilful and complacent ignorance. Almost no news coverage of how that very same economic growth is relentlessly fucking the environment and the ecosystems that we depend on', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526904452000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18309811', u'id': u'116055431', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Malware', u'text': u'I don't understand the problem. We'll build pollinating drones!', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526928905000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4243084', u'id': u'116070582', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AngrySkeptic', u'text': u'One significant problem is that we humans seem to have placed money above everything else and it leads to the "development" we see all over the world. The other problem is our habit of seeing other creatures a "pests" to be eradicated, rather than other living beings that share the planet with us. As humans have become ever more urbanised our knowledge of animals has been greatly reduced and we them as getting in the way, except for our chosen pets. We also regularly mistreat the earth itself, with little thought about the geology and ecology on which life depends. To reverse these ingrained attitudes will be an almost impossible task. Today's Guardian carries a report about using robots to replace doctors and nurses in some aspects of health care. It is not what sick people need and I would not appreciate it. But here we are in a world that puts its love of technology above human considerations. What hope is there for animals and plants?
My view of humanity grows darker by the day. It is not the result of increasing age, but the realisation that education has not improved us as a species, has not opened our eyes nor our imaginations. I know a lot of first rate young people, many of whom care and have a social conscience, but countries are governed by mature people with vested interests and outlooks that are not easily changed, except by catastrophies that touch them personally. So, we do what we can. For my part, I have a garden given over to a mix of local plants, fruit trees, and vegetables, bird feeders and a birdbath. Some "weeds" are allowed to flourish. Local wildlife comes and goes at will. Absolutely NO pesticides! A few neighbours do likewise.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526927907000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it', u'effect': u'the development'}], u'author_id': u'11577802', u'in_reply_to': u'116069116', u'id': u'116070209', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'krnlgmp', u'text': u'If they're spraying your flowers, it'd only be fair for you to dig up their patio. How we relate to other species is important.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526926355000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11577802', u'in_reply_to': u'116069129', u'id': u'116069559', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Harvestingkarma', u'text': u'Block paving increases flood waters, and there are no weeds only wild flowers which may try to grow up. The insects need the wild flowers. People are lazy to use sprays and not do the labour. Hedgies will keep down slug and snail but are territorial and can climb but they are also great ratters. I love wild flowers as they attract the wild insects. Dandelions, daisies, globe flowers, valerian etc all are loved by insects. Ragweed is toxic until dried out but it helps balance the soil.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526898639000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16314139', u'in_reply_to': u'116042853', u'id': u'116051062', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonathanHughes', u'text': u'Sorry for the long answer - that was just a few ideas', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526925217000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12031469', u'in_reply_to': u'116068601', u'id': u'116069129', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonathanHughes', u'text': u'As you rightly say there are a number of issues (regarding insects we are probably talking pesticides, CCD (for bees), habitat destruction (and fragmentation)
As to what we can do individually there are a great many things, preodmoninantly round our gardening habits and support for companies that produce food using fewer pesticides.
As a society there are a great many things - 
1. ban neonics (it cannot be stressed strongly enough how important this is) - it does seem to be the case that the EU are close to banning it
2. Stop building so many roads - habitat fragmentation is a death knell for wildlife, you can actually calculate pretty accurately how much each habitat 'downsizing' - for example if you drive a motorwa or bypass through the middle of half the woodland you don't just create a minor barrier you create two sperate woodlands exactly half the size of the previous one - you then get a pretty linear decline in species numbers and total biomass.
3. Shift to public transport - car usage (as well as needing more roads) increases nitrogen content near roads which causes homogenisation of plants (cow parlsely, nettles and brambles do well - other things such as poppies and other flowers that have evolved to do well in low nitrogen soils do worse) and this has a knock on effect on the diversity of species that can be supported.
4. More joined up planning - the ever increasing trend for these estates of 3/4/5 bedroom houses outside towns that have no amenities and no bus access is driving the eating up of habitat.
5. Stop paving over gardens (which I appreciate you might not have done!) but it's a real scourge!
6. Support (and government needs to fund) programmes to reduce invasive species, for insects things like rhododendron might seem good but they are hugely invasive and drive out pretty much all other plants (which leads to a reduction in insect biodveirsty)
7. Support local wildlife trusts - this one is important as wildlife trusts (when they can) buy new land to be protected (in Norfolk for example they bought Hickling broad about a year ago - it's the largest and most important broad for wildlife)', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526925183000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'which', u'effect': u'homogenisation of plants'}, {u'cause': u'which', u'effect': u'a reduction in insect biodveirsty'}], u'author_id': u'12031469', u'in_reply_to': u'116068601', u'id': u'116069116', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Harvestingkarma', u'text': u'Governments may be career building and business building! The vote is a kind of soother of the people. I think the governments kind of have ways of making sure the party that gets in is the one that the top johnnies think is right for us. What should be done about those standing in the way?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526923679000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11577802', u'in_reply_to': u'116043765', u'id': u'116068601', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'NasalBowhog', u'text': u'I've encouraged wildlife in our garden by digging a pond and leaving an area to grow wild, planting cherry and plum trees, whilst several of my neighbors have put down plastic grass or paved over areas to cut down on the time spent maintaining. Have planted quite a few and taken down dying, we now have deer and badgers on the site have also seen lizards, slow worms and many butterflies', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526898234000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3840915', u'in_reply_to': u'116050684', u'id': u'116050773', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Harvestingkarma', u'text': u'Try planting trees and see if the tree charities might do that.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526898108000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16314139', u'in_reply_to': u'116044634', u'id': u'116050684', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Calbum', u'text': u'It rarely mentions that the coming changes will severely hurt the industries doing the most damage (Subsidised Meat, Dairy and Monocrops), more expensive fuel (Pound strength) and Flight emissions (13% of UK emissions, Open Skies).
Coming agricultural reform, ability to ban live animal exports, the opportunities are endless.
This coming shakeup is THE perfect opportunity too talk and educate our populous on the negatives aspects of our economic model (Perhaps the only opportunity we will ever get) and perhaps start working towards a better future but no, business as usual, growth growth growth.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526919568000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14740283', u'in_reply_to': u'116055431', u'id': u'116066511', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Calbum', u'text': u'Nice too see an article on ways we can help, thankyou.
That is exactly what I have done! Not got a Garden sadly (9th floor of tower block) but have managed to get an allotment plot.
I really hope I have developed it into a 'stepping stone' for nature! I have long ago decided to make it into a perma-culture plot with a focus on flowers and fruit (Berries).
I have a nice pond which I counted 16 adult newts this spring, they laid a mass of newt spawn larger than a football. Its not got a lining and I think they have intentionally kicked up the silt for camouflage, I now occasionally see a baby newt come too the surface for air, it's lovely.
I cannot currently move around my home as it is full of seedling flowers, about 200 poppy plants and 100 Hollyhocks (Never plant ALL your seeds), I have lavender, cyclamen and a few other plants + a whole bunch of stuff that has wild-seeded itself. 
One wild Aqualigia = Must get more Aqualigia.
I am more interested in permanent - perennial flowers which the insects love (And preferably producing berries which the birds love).
Any suggestions?
Eventually ill be hanging woven bee hives which will never be harvested.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526918440000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14740283', u'id': u'116065848', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Harvestingkarma', u'text': u'I have a courtyard garden full of trees in pots and I let any wildflower/weed grow as it wishes. Collecting seed for grass and flowers might take a few hours!', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526895402000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3889018', u'in_reply_to': u'116044634', u'id': u'116048771', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'richardjwilliams', u'text': u'"This is on top of the alarming collapse reported in Germany, where 75% of the flying insect biomass has vanished from protected areas in less than 30 years" Excpt what they and the Uni of East Anglia don't mention is a) it' almost impossible to wipe out insects ( Mosquitoes as an example) and b) in many cases localised variations do not indicate eradication but movement to other environs which may or may not be attributed to climate change.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526895295000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3889018', u'id': u'116048685', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Hebegebe', u'text': u'Just reread that and it came out slightly wrong... what I meant was wouldn't the insects just get killed by cars.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526892792000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16217467', u'in_reply_to': u'116035471', u'id': u'116046840', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Raptorius', u'text': u'BQSTART
but feel there could be financial assistance
BQEND
As if letting nature run its course on a piece of land requires financial incentives for hobbyists. Imagine if everyone asked for that, we'll soon have people just giving up because the concept of ''nature capital'' runs on thin ice to begin with.
Ever thought about becoming a farmer? You got the right mind for it....', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526892619000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the concept of runs on thin ice to begin with', u'effect': u'people just giving up'}], u'author_id': u'17632173', u'in_reply_to': u'116044634', u'id': u'116046699', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Raptorius', u'text': u'Yes, but then it gets far more complicated then that. Every political party represents a number of ideals and the average voter can't be pigeon holed into clear camps of right or left. People vote for the right, they get more indifference towards intensive agriculture and air pollution. People vote for the left, and then they get more immigrants who also require space, housing, and increase congestion.
Our vote matters but it's not like when we vote we agree 100% on everything the party stands for..', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526892317000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17632173', u'in_reply_to': u'116044565', u'id': u'116046488', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'fistjobdenial', u'text': u'A third of my allotment is currently seeded with wild grass and flowers. I have an acre in the Country with which I intend to do the same but feel there could be financial assistance', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526889298000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3840915', u'id': u'116044634', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'letsbeclearaboutthis', u'text': u'Governments are elected. They are responsive to public opinion. Individuals matter. They vote.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526889184000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2385135', u'in_reply_to': u'116043566', u'id': u'116044565', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'letsbeclearaboutthis', u'text': u'It wasn't until I started keeping bees and chooks (on my 400 sq.m. lifestyle block) that I became aware of how harmful pest control products are. Now I rely on the chooks to keep slugs, snails, grass grubs, caterpillars and cockroaches under control, as well as keeping the borders weedfree. Any obstinate weeds get the boiling water treatment. The bees improve pollination of fruit. I get eggs and honey. Win-win.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526889055000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2385135', u'id': u'116044489', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'aldebaranredstar', u'text': u'The plants that have the neonicotinoids in them should be labeled as such and you can avoid buying them.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526888979000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4482287', u'in_reply_to': u'116035096', u'id': u'116044444', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'aldebaranredstar', u'text': u'Humans are innately selfish, unfortunately. But gov't can do more to educate and incentivize, encourage.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526888771000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4482287', u'in_reply_to': u'116035852', u'id': u'116044340', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'aldebaranredstar', u'text': u'In China, they hand-pollinate because there is no other way. Sad.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526888709000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'there is no other way', u'effect': u'in china they hand pollinate'}], u'author_id': u'4482287', u'in_reply_to': u'116036066', u'id': u'116044311', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'aldebaranredstar', u'text': u'Where I live we recently lost power due to falling trees taking down the wires. We lost power for 3 days and it was great! I felt much more at peace in my body--less stress, tension etc. I had no cell phone signal during that time, no TV, no computer internet, no refrigerator whining away, no heating system going on and off and vibrating, no electric fans, no microwaves, no EMR. These things, which supposedly bring us 'comfort," are actually destroying things, including our good mental states and our physical health. It's not surprising that it affects other, smaller, species that depend on magnetic forces that are natural. After the power went back on, I made a resolution not to use all that power as I once did and took for granted. It's not an easy resolution as it involves breaking all those bad habits. When the power went off, I had to go to bed early and I got up with the sun--a natural lifestyle. The internet, although it brings good articles and comments like this, is also a way to fritter away energy and time in destructive ways, all the while burning up the planet's resources, and our own. I guess I have to move out to a place that's completely off grid??', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526888659000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'falling trees taking down the wires', u'effect': u'where i live we recently lost power'}], u'author_id': u'4482287', u'in_reply_to': u'116036098', u'id': u'116044283', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TheWatchingPlace', u'text': u'This is a somewhat daft argument becase both climate change and environmental pollution/toxicity are affecting insect population and there is plenty of scientific study that has or is being undertaken in both areas.
It is true that insects have survived much more extreme temperatures in the past, but what is harder for them to overcome is the altered timing of what we call 'life history' events - eg: this study talks about how the close relationship between certain insects and their host plants may be affected by climate change, this in turn reduces habitat availability for some and increases it for others. Climate change will produce winners and losers in the insect world, but it will almost certainly affect species abundance and composition.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526888444000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11457348', u'in_reply_to': u'116039861', u'id': u'116044175', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonathanHughes', u'text': u'Roundup is a herbicide isn't it? (Apologies if wrog). There is no need at all for gardens to be treated with anything. There is a more complex conversation about farming but gardens - have a few weeds and insects', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526887854000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12031469', u'in_reply_to': u'116033260', u'id': u'116043867', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonathanHughes', u'text': u'Astroturf lawns are the dumbest thing. There was a story in here someone told - his neighbour dug up her lawn and replaced it with astroturf - he asked her why and she said it was too much hassle to mow it. She told him his after her weekly hoovering of the astroturf', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526887758000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12031469', u'in_reply_to': u'116028844', u'id': u'116043814', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonathanHughes', u'text': u'But 'your garden'is not the same as ' all the world'. It's not a case of people agreeing with me - the massive decline in wildlife is not an opinion it's it's fact. Either wildlife has declined (it has) athuge rates or it hasn't.
Bee numbers, as an example are crashing around the world and across species and colony collapse disorder and a seemingly almost overnight inability of various species to cope with varoa mite infestations (which they've dealt with easily for generations) appear to be the case. And the route cause of those seems to be pesticide use (especially neonocitinoids). 
Your garden may have lots of insects (I bet you the average garden has a lot fewer insects than 50 years ago) but go walk through a farmer's field - very few.
Walk thought a woodland nature reserve at this time of year and you'll be astounded how noisy it is with birds and insects, then walk through a patch of woodland in between crop fields - the difference in sound is extraordinariy', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526887660000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12031469', u'in_reply_to': u'116039174', u'id': u'116043765', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'aldebaranredstar', u'text': u'Recently I read an article from an environmental magazine explaining that electric cars are not the solution. Why? electricity is not generated by pollution-free methods. Electricity is produced by various awful means that add to pollution, whereas, according to the article, cars are actually more efficient now and burn less fuel and emit less pollutants (I am not talking about diesel but regular lead free gas/petrol).', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526887495000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4482287', u'in_reply_to': u'116042617', u'id': u'116043685', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, ...]
description: Insects are the backbone of a healthy global ecosystem – but their numbers are facing catastrophic decline due to climate change. So, what can you do to help?
headline: d
og_fields.og:description: Insects are the backbone of a healthy global ecosystem – but their numbers are facing catastrophic decline due to climate change. So, what can you do to help?
og_fields.og:title: Save our bugs! How to avert an insect Armageddon
text:
Already beset by degraded landscapes and a toxic environment, insects are going to suffer a catastrophic decline in numbers unless climate change is controlled, according to new research from the University of East Anglia. This is on top of the alarming collapse reported in Germany, where 75% of the flying insect biomass has vanished from protected areas in less than 30 years.
Insects are the backbone of a healthy ecosystem and the consequences of their absence will be global. Is there anything we can do other than despair? Insects will need stepping stones to move around the country as the climate changes. Here are some ways you can help.
If you have a garden, make it part of the solution. Insects need food and we have destroyed 97% of our wildlflower meadows. The charity Buglife has a great guide that shows which plants help which insects: winter flowers such as hellebore, erica and mahonia for pollinators such as bees; evergreen shrubs and climbers for bugs such as woodlice and spiders.
Insects need water – make sure you have some in your garden. Watching bees drink at the bird bath is fun; better still is watching dragonflies emerge from your wildlife pond.
Look beyond your own patch and lobby your council to turn verges into highways for insects. Plants help insects, which help mammals, bats, amphibians, reptiles and birds to thrive. We need to fix the system, not just an isolated component.
B-Lines, a series of insect pathways running through the countryside, are the best way to help on a national scale. You can help by writing to your MP and asking them to support Ben Bradley’s Protection for Pollinators bill. The “B-Line bill” will make the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs take this innovative landscape ecological solution seriously. It passed the first stage of the process through parliament unopposed.

description: New book by bestselling historian argues global challenges will make nations ever more interdependent
headline: N
og_fields.og:description: New book by bestselling historian argues global challenges will make nations ever more interdependent
og_fields.og:title: Yuval Noah Harari: Brexit will not halt drive to 'human unification'
text:
Brexit could prove to be a mere bump on the road toward “human unification”, according to a new book by bestselling historian Yuval Noah Harari, which warns politicians against becoming distracted by the rise of nationalism in the world.
The Israeli academic, whose first book, Sapiens, became a surprise publishing sensation by charting the rise of the human species, turns his attention to current affairs for the first time with a swipe at what he argues is a short-sighted response to global challenges in countries such as the UK, US, Russia and Israel.
“Brexit may well initiate the simultaneous unravelling of both the UK and the EU. But in the long run, history’s direction is clear cut,” he writes. “In recent generations the few remaining civilisations have been blending into a single global civilisation.”
The new book, 21 lessons for the 21st Century, is published in August and comes amid a period of unprecedented introspection in British politics over how to leave the European Union. Yet Harari argues the coming challenges of global warming, technological disruption and nuclear proliferation will make us “ever more interdependent” and in need of cooperative projects such as the EU.
“In a different century and different situation, I don’t think there is anything necessarily wrong about Brexit,” he added in an interview. “If you want to be a completely independent country and not part of a bigger organisation, then fine. The problem is that given the kind of challenges we face today, the opportunity costs of being very self absorbed are becoming higher and higher all the time.”
The thesis may infuriate Brexit supporters who regard it as a way for Britain to look out to the world more, but Harari also has words of criticism for liberals who regard the EU referendum as a catastrophe.
“Like a person imagining that a bad headache signifies a terminal brain tumour, many liberals fear that Brexit and the rise of Donald Trump portend the end of human civilisation,” he writes. “The first step is to tone down the prophecies of gloom and switch from panic mode to bewilderment … more humble, and therefore more clear-sighted.”
He also claims it is not inevitable that humanity will learn to collaborate more, warning of a possible “unravelling” of the EU in the wake of Brexit – with worrying implications.
“If the European project fails … it would indicate that belief in the liberal values of freedom and tolerance is not enough to resolve the cultural conflicts of the world,” writes Harari. “If Greeks and Germans cannot agree on a common destiny, and if 500 million affluent Europeans cannot absorb a few million impoverished refugees, what chances do humans have of overcoming the far deeper conflicts that beset our global civilisation?”
“Let’s say the rise of artificial intelligence completely disrupts the global job market, this will create far far bigger social and economic challenges than the immigration of a few million people to the EU or some workers from Poland and Romania to the UK,” he added.
Harari, who lectures at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, was also critical of Israeli nationalism in the wake of the killing of Palestinian protesters last week.
“If every nation thinks about itself, then who is thinking about the global problems?” he said. “I don’t see Israel making any significant contribution to confronting the main challenges of humankind.”
But the book singles out the EU as a model for how national interests can be balanced and what is at stake if it fails.
“After centuries of terrible bloodshed, French, Germans, Italians and Britons have finally built a mechanism that ensures continental harmony – only to have the British public throw a spanner into the miracle machine,” writes Harari.
“We have a global ecology, a global economy and a global science – but we are still stuck with only national politics,” he adds. “To have effective politics we must either deglobalise the ecology, the economy or the march of science – or we must globalise our politics.”

We're up against the Wombledon Wanderers next week and we need to work on our defence. Don't talk to me about sticky wickets and un-willing precipitants, I've played the worst of them.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527598873000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3684556', u'in_reply_to': u'116366713', u'id': u'116370344', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'When the water starts rising in the ship, the rats head for the higher decks or the rigging. Fact is for them, is that it was science that identified all these natural cycles (from AMO to glacials) - and it was science that identified the warming properties of CO2. Surprisingly often in reverse and mixed order. 
I think the latter mess with their thought process (that seems to be very linear, maybe from how school pedagoics work). 
It is if they got a glimpse of Popper at some social science of science class, and think that Poppers critical rationalism is a descriptive theory and the fact that properties of CO2 being discovered before Newtonian motion of our planet was nailed, somehow break science. 
The good trend is that the pletoria of "alternative theories" are heavily reduced, though. 
We have been in the age or sun-spots. We have been in the age of ocean outgassing. We have been through the age of cosmic rays and even the odd "pole-switch" theory. 
Sure - there are still some stuck in the 80s, when hemispheric analysis put a huge damper on the local analysis of UK grape harvests during the medieval. 
But in general, it is now more about misunderstanding of science instead of made up science. 
These days, the argument seems to gravitate towards vulcanos under Antarctica a lot. Gone are the days when volcanoes were wrongly argued to be the source of CO2. There is a new kid in town - they melt Anarctica from below. 
This is of course correct. This planet has geothermal heat. It is important. Lake Vostok is not exactly new. But in terms of causality for observed AGW it is down the list with solar activity, orbital configuration and similar information discovered and brought to attention by - hey - science. 
The only non-scientific argument that lives happily these days is the global conspiracy theory of science (but strangely not for companies that has own value vested). 
And still - for those in social science and political argument, the snowball and a hailstorm is still valid argument of global cooling.', u'recommendation_count': u'23', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527534701000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4706143', u'in_reply_to': u'116334970', u'id': u'116341534', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Samuel', u'text': u'Oh dear. description: John Abraham: Hot oceans fueled Hurricane Harvey, generating more intense rainfall
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: John Abraham: Hot oceans fueled Hurricane Harvey, generating more intense rainfall
og_fields.og:title: Global warming made Hurricane Harvey more destructive | John Abraham
text:
Last summer, the United states was pummeled with three severe hurricanes in rapid succession. It was a truly awesome display of the power of weather and the country is still reeling from the effects. In the climate community, there has been years of research into the effect that human-caused global warming has on these storms – both their frequency and their power. 
The prevailing view is that in a warming world, there will likely be fewer such storms, but the storms that form will be more severe. Some research, however, concludes that there will be both more storms and more severe ones. More generally, because there is more heat, there is more activity, which can be manifested in several ways.
Regardless, there is very little doubt that a warmer planet can create more powerful storms. The reason is that hurricanes feed off of warmer ocean water. In order to form these storms, oceans have to be above about 26°C (about 80°F). With waters that hot, and with strong winds, there is a rapid evaporation of moisture from the ocean. The resulting water vapor enters into the storm, providing the energy to power the storm as the water vapor condenses and falls out of the storm as rain.
As a large hurricane passes over warm water, it sucks in heat not only from the top layer of water but also from quite deep in the ocean, at least 160 meters (approximately 525 feet) or more. The main way heat is pulled out of the ocean is through the aforementioned evaporation process. There are also smaller effects from mixing the ocean waters and blocking sunlight to the ocean. Basically, when a hurricane passes over warm waters, the ocean “sweats” and cools off – a process enabled by the strong winds. The image below shows this evaporation and condensation process.
A very recent publication in the journal Earth’s Future studied the impact of hurricanes on warm oceans in order to understand how warm waters fuel the storms and also how storms affect the water temperatures. With Hurricane Harvey, a near perfect natural laboratory was available in the Gulf of Mexico. Temperature measurements are plentiful there and the scientists were able to measure the total ocean heat content in the upper 160 meters just before Hurricane Harvey passed and compare the heat measured after the storm. 
What they found was very interesting. As seen in the image below, before the storm (top frame), the ocean heat content was very high (red colors). After the hurricane passed (bottom frame), the waters were notably cooler. 
The scientists calculated that the waters lost approximately 6 x 1020 Joules of heat because of Harvey. That’s about 10 million times as much energy as the atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima. Then the scientists used rainfall data and calculated how much heat fell in the form of rain. The results were a nearly perfect match with the energy taken up by the storm. That is, they were able to balance the energy and water flows into and out of the storm to a very high level of accuracy.
With the passage of the hurricane and the “cold wake,” it made the scientists consider how future storms would be impacted. That is, any storms following Harvey would pass over a cooler ocean and should not be as intense as Harvey was. 
The researchers discovered that the so-called “cold wake” was still hot enough to fuel future storms. The surface temperatures were reduced by about 2°C (3°F), but remained above the threshold needed to fuel hurricanes. The reason why the waters remained hot was that the temperatures before Harvey were off-the-charts hot because of human warming. Just before Harvey, ocean waters both globally and in the Gulf of Mexico were at record temperatures.
So, what does this all mean? First of all, the balancing of energy flow into and out of a hurricane is a tremendous accomplishment and it validates much of what is understood about these storms. Secondly, this study shows that storms can become more violent in a warming world. Not only that, but there is the potential of getting very active seasons, as occurred in 2017. All of this is related to the high water temperatures not only at the ocean surface but also deep beneath the surface.

description: Government advisers call for changes to Direct Action policy to end investment in schemes that do not reduce emissions
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Government advisers call for changes to Direct Action policy to end investment in schemes that do not reduce emissions
og_fields.og:title: Emissions scheme wastes millions on projects that would have gone ahead anyway
text:
Independent experts advising the Turnbull government have called for changes to the Coalition’s Direct Action climate policy to prevent tens of millions of dollars of public money going to projects that would have gone ahead anyway.
 The recommendation is in a review of the $2.55bn emissions reduction fund, the central plank of Direct Action, which pays landowners and companies to avoid emissions or sequester carbon dioxide in plants at the lowest cost. The fund is supposed to support projects that would reduce Australia’s carbon pollution below what it would otherwise have been.
 But the Emissions Reduction Assurance Committee found one type of project – existing landfill sites that capture methane, a potent greenhouse gas, from decomposing rubbish and burn it to generate energy – already make enough money from the sale of electricity and renewable energy certificates to cover their costs and were mostly likely to continue without taxpayer support. The report was published online in late March. 
 It follows long-standing criticism that the emissions reduction fund is in some cases not delivering the cuts the government has promised. Critics say under the current design it is creating “junk” carbon credits that do not represent actual reductions, but are used by industry and government to offset emissions. 
 The committee recommended that no electricity generating landfill gas projects currently receiving carbon credits be given extensions when agreements lapse. Most existing contracts run to 2021 or longer. 
The University of Melbourne legal academic Tim Baxter, who has published peer-reviewed research revealing flaws in the fund, said the change was long overdue.
 He said several analyses had suggested many of the emissions reductions paid for from the fund were not genuine as they would have happened without spending more than $2bn of taxpayers’ money. Landfill gas was probably the worst example, he said.
 “There is no way that 191m tonnes of abatement is being kept in the ground or sequestered (as the government has claimed),” Baxter said. “Based on the design and accounting, we are either counting abatement that they were already doing or we’re counting emissions they were not going to be released anyway.”
The emissions reduction fund is the only policy the Coalition has legislated to cut emissions. It was hastily devised by then opposition environment spokesman Greg Hunt after Tony Abbott took the Liberal leadership in December 2009 promising to oppose carbon pricing, and introduced in 2014.
 Landfill gas projects have long been controversial inclusions in the Direct Action scheme, largely because about three-quarters of them were already operating before the emissions reduction fund was created in 2014.
 Half of the projects received payments under the defunct New South Wales greenhouse gas reduction scheme (the world’s first mandatory emissions scheme) or the federal greenhouse friendly offsets program that shut in 2010. Labor and the Greens offered continued support by including them in the Carbon Farming Initiative set up in 2011. The Coalition extended it further by including them in the list of projects that could win funding under Direct Action.
 All parties received departmental or agency advice that they may be crediting projects that were likely to happen anyway, and therefore not cutting emissions below what they otherwise would have been. 
 Baxter said it was a transparent case of political expediency overruling good policy.
 “For the sake of being able to say ‘our scheme per tonne of emissions is cheaper than the previous government’s scheme’ you’re seeing essentially junk credits being created,” he said.
 “These projects are allowed into the fund to make the price cheaper based on a spurious argument that if we don’t provide credits that these worthwhile landfill gas projects would close. There is no evidence that any of these projects were at or near closure.”
 Iain Macgill, from the University of NSW’s Centre for Energy and Environmental Markets, welcomed the committee’s recommendation but said the evidence that landfill gas should be excluded was not new, and suggested it should be extended to cover other projects that just flared methane emissions but did not generate electricity. “Why has it taken so long to address?” he said.
 Macgill said emissions from landfills needed to be cut but policy efforts would be better focused on reducing the proportion of waste being dumped.
Environment minister Josh Frydenberg did not directly respond to questions about whether he would accept the committee’s recommendation. He said a departmental review of climate policies last year confirmed Australia had a comprehensive set of emission reduction policies and the emissions reduction fund was internationally recognised as one of the world’s largest domestic carbon offset markets.
 Emissions from waste increased 1% last year, part of an overall increase in national emissions of 1.5%.
 Under Labor and the Greens, the credits would have been paid for by businesses offsetting their emissions. Under Direct Action, their main source of income to date is public money.
 The government has 87 existing emissions contracts with landfill gas projects, promised to prevent about 20m tonnes of emissions – about 4% of what Australia emits each year. Assuming landfill operators are paid the average price of $11.90 per tonne of carbon dioxide, they would be getting $243m worth of carbon credits from taxpayers.
 This is likely to be an overestimate. The emissions reduction fund works as a reverse auction – the lowest credible bids win government contracts. Given they have existing revenue streams for their electricity, landfill operators could bid in at a price less than the average. Some estimates suggest they may be paid about half the average price.
 About half of the promised emissions cuts are contracted with one company, Adelaide-based LMS Energy. The rest are spread across several companies and councils. They included energy giants AGL and EnergyAustralia, though AGL sold its landfill gas generation assets last month. LMS Energy declined to comment on the proposed changes.
 In a research paper with Dr George Gilligan published in the Australian Journal of Environmental Law in December, Baxter found the emissions reduction fund had been set up to include landfill gas projects even though they should not qualify based on three tests built into the legislation to ensure all projects were “additional” – that they are delivering carbon abatement that would not happened anyway. 
 In simple terms, the three tests are that each project must be new, not have access to other government funding and not be required by other laws or regulations.
 For landfill gas, Baxter said the last two tests were overruled by a declaration that being a methane-capture-and-combustion project alone was enough to qualify, regardless of other circumstances. The “newness” test has been overridden by ministerial decision.
 “Two of the three tests are replaced with a statement that ‘a landfill gas operator is a landfill gas operator’. It’s just nuts,” Baxter said. “It is legal because it is built into the act, but it is of questionable morality. It is a neutering of the letter of the law and the spirit of the law.”
 The independent expert review comes as the Clean Energy Regulator, the government agency that runs the emissions reduction fund, prepares for its seventh auction on 6 and 7 June. To date, $2.285bn has been contracted, leaving $265m to spend.
The Clean Energy Regulator chairman, David Parker, told a Senate estimates hearing last week that he expected contracts worth between $50m and $100m would be signed in June.

This model is no longer viable. 
Despite your need to deny it (the vehement repetition of "no") you were making a case for the economic necessity of working people to do their best to survive by getting jobs in the petrol, steel and the auto industries. 
Let's start over with your last statement: 
"I am trying to understand why [Trump] and other climate change deniers think the way [they] do."
Your first attempt to explain this phenomenon was a psychological one (hence the fight and flight references). I agree that this, in a primative sense, is an instinctual need to survive but you also brought up concepts like "freedom" and perceived threats. These are political matters and subject to ideology and propaganda. Anyone who watches a Murdoch news source for any length of time will adopt the perceived threats that that source supplies. This includes scapegoats, foreigners and jobstealers and you name it. It is hardly any wonder that people believe such hoodoo devil dolls that are shaken before them daily. 
I've tried to explain that the opposition of "oeconomics" and oecology is an illusory one but it is a very widespread idea. To dispel this illusion requires at the very least a return to the related meanings of the two words.

I am trying to explain to you why Trump believes what he does, and why his supporters believe it too. I am not agreeing with it. I am not asking you to agree with it. I am trying to explain it.
Got that?
Trump opposes the concept of man-made climate change because he sees it as a threat to him. I am not saying he is right. I am not saying that you should think the way he does. I am explaining Trump to you.
I then go on to say in my original post that not doing something about climate change is the bigger threat. The Trump point of view may be superficially attractive because he is addressing a short-term threat. But it does not work in the long term because climate change is a much bigger threat.

... as NASA’s Dr Gavin Schmidt has pointed out, the IPCC’s implied best guess was that humans were responsible for around 110% of observed warming (ranging from 72% to 146%), with natural factors in isolation leading to a slight cooling over the past 50 years. 
Similarly, the recent US fourth national climate assessment* found that between 93% to 123% of observed 1951-2010 warming was due to human activities.
These conclusions have led to some confusion as to how more than 100% of observed warming could be attributable to human activity. It depends which definition of the phrase "climate change" they use by default in their research.
From the IPCC's AR5 "Annex III : Glossary" :
BQSTART
Climate change : Climate change refers to a change in the state of the climate that can be identified (e.g., by using statistical tests) by changes in the mean and/or the variability of its properties, and that persists for an extended period, typically decades or longer. Climate change may be due to natural internal processes or external forcings such as modulations of the solar cycles, volcanic eruptions and persistent anthropogenic changes in the composition of the atmosphere or in land use. 
Note that the Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), in its Article 1, defines climate change as: ‘a change of climate which is attributed directly or indirectly to human activity that alters the composition of the global atmosphere and which is in addition to natural climate variability observed over comparable time periods’. The UNFCCC thus makes a distinction between climate change attributable to human activities altering the atmospheric composition, and climate variability attributable to natural causes.
BQEND
Any scientists using the UNFCCC definitions will distinguish between "(100% anthropogenic) climate change" and "(100% natural) climate variability".
People like myself (and the OP if I'm not mistaken ...) who prefer the IPCC definition will be confused for a few seconds (at least) if the term "climate change" is used in the UNFCCC manner without clarification.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527960134000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'natural internal processes or external forcings such as modulations of the solar cycles', u'effect': u'climate change may be'}], u'author_id': u'3985037', u'in_reply_to': u'116495029', u'id': u'116523937', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'sophiia2222', u'text': u'Welcome.

Similar, there is zero question about principles of AGW. Doubling of CO2 gives a one degree direct effect, 2-5 degrees with feedbacks. 
If it is 2 or 5 degrees in an open feedback system is a range largely representing the complexity of the open system peaking by both historical and different theoretical considerations to land around 3 degrees. 
To use cosmology as an example is a bit like biting yourself in the foot. Those guys are applying philosophy of mathematics to probe what is possible to make sense of. It is pure theory - and in terms of standard science, they do have a problem because many of these theories struggle giving measurable hypotsis for testing. 
Climate science does not rewrite fundamental physics. It is all applied classic theory (with a bit of quantum physics and relativity thrown in). 
Remember - high-end satellites use applied science to record how fast oxygen atoms vibrate at some optical depth in the atmosphere. Classic science - transfered back to degrees Kelvin. 
US secret labs did huge amount of science on how CO2 and water blocks heat post Ww2 - because they designed heat-seeking missiles. 
Black body calculations are important for many things. If you treat Earth as a black body object you quickly realise that it would be quite chilly here. The greenhouse effect is a pretty big thing. 
And the fact is that we knew this a long time before we even discovered that black holes could exist in theory. The theory of AGW is not resting on the potential information paradox of black holes. 
Remember - Newtonian physics still works fine even though it was puzzled together centuries before anyone started pondering new data suggesting that the entire universe is expanding instead of being steady state. 
The rather fun (and surpringly accurate) game of "Kerbal" allows us to play around with the same physics NASA used for suborbital, orbital and extraorbital physics. It is not like the international space station instantly fell to the ground after Hawkins shared doubts about our understanding of deep cosmology. 
It is similar with AGW physics. A lot of physics is sand-boxed - because of scale. If Higgs had not been discovered, it would not have changed the effect of mass we live with. A big sledge to the head would still hurt. BQENDThe IPCC synthesis report is the summation of literally thousands of reports.

This changes nothing - AGW is still as real as ever and the science is now irrefutable - but I think that makes all the more important that we accept the science as it is presented to us without any of the exaggeration or undue emphasis that, no matter how well intended, a number of people wish to apply to it.

Climate updates - What have we learnt since the IPCC 5th Assessment Report?
