grow in size and enter the Red Giant phase of its evolution. It is calculated that the expanding Sun will grow large enough to encompass the orbit’s of Mercury, Venus, and maybe even Earth. description: With a target to halve its huge carbon footprint, the race is on to find new technologies to green the world’s shipping fleet
og_fields.og:description: With a target to halve its huge carbon footprint, the race is on to find new technologies to green the world’s shipping fleet
og_fields.og:title: Future sailors: what will ships look like in 30 years?
text:
Watch out for the return of the sailing ship.
After a commitment last month to cut greenhouse gas emissions from shipping by at least 50% by 2050, the race is on to find new technologies that can green the 50,000-strong global shipping fleet. Wind power is one of the options being discussed.
International shipping accounts for more than 2% of global carbon dioxide emissions, roughly the same as aircraft. But the 2015 Paris agreement to fight climate change left control of the shipping industry’s emissions to the International Maritime Organisation.
While environment groups applauded the agreement to cut hard and deep by 2050, they pointed out that it falls far short what is technically achievable.
A report published just before the meeting by the International Transport Forum (ITF), a thinktank run by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), found that the industry could achieve up to 95% decarbonisation as early as 2035 using “maximum deployment of currently known technologies.”
Low-tech solutions
The good news is that easy-to-do low-tech solutions can deliver a lot. Maersk, the world’s largest container shipping line, has already discovered it can cut fuel use 30% simply by steaming more slowly.
Because of the wide availability of cheap (and often dirty) fuel, shipping has traditionally been wasteful. Most merchant ships are made of heavy steel rather than lighter aluminium, and don’t bother with obvious energy-saving measures like low-friction hull coatings or recovering waste heat.
More slender ship designs alone could cut fuel use — and hence emissions — by 10-15% at slow speeds and up to 25% at high speeds, says the ITF. But replacing the existing fleet would take time. The average age of today’s shipping fleet is 25 years. Rules of energy efficiency for new ships introduced by the IMO in 2013 will only fully come into force from 2030, meaning that any switch to slender ships would not apply to most ships at sea until mid-century or beyond.
But much could be done more quickly by retrofitting existing ships with technology to cut their fuel use and hence emissions, according to the ITF. Here are just four:
Fitting ships’ bows with a bulbous extension below the water line reduces drag enough to cut emissions 2-7%;
A technique known as air lubrication, which pumps compressed air below the hull to create a carpet of bubbles, also reduces drag and can cut emissions by a further 3%;
Replacing one propeller with two rotating in opposite directions recovers slipstream energy and can make efficiency gains of 8-15%,
Cleaning the hull and painting it with a low-friction coating can deliver gains of up to 5%.
Entirely new ships
Putting together better designs and better fuel will create entirely new kinds of ships in future. And the blueprints are already being drawn up.
The Aquarius Ecoship, a cargo ship devised by a Japanese company called Eco Marine Power, is driven by a phalanx of rigid sails and solar panels. The same system could power oil tankers, cruise ships and much else. It would not, the designers admit, entirely eliminate the need for conventional fuel: Even with large batteries to store the solar and wind energy, back-up would be needed. But it could cut emissions by 40 percent.
Going one better, the Japanese shipping line NYK boasts that its design for a 350m-long container ship, the Super Eco Ship 2030, would use LNG to make hydrogen to run fuel cells. Backed up by solar panels covering the entire ship and 4,000 square metres of sails to catch the wind, the combination could cut emissions by 70%. Or for a completely zero-carbon option, engineers at Wallenius Wilhelmsen, a Scandinavian shipping line, offer the E/S Orcelle, a lightweight cargo ship designed to transport up to 10,000 cars (electric, we trust) on eight decks.
It would be powered by electricity, half coming directly from wind, solar and wave energy, and the other half from converting some of that energy into hydrogen to power fuel cells. The company says the ship could be afloat by 2025.
Today’s ships are in many respects almost indistinguishable from those of a century ago. But the IMO decision to finally get with the global climate agenda has fired the starting gun on what is set to be a race to create a new standard for low-carbon shipping that should be the norm just a few decades from now.
Banishing conventional fuel
Some of the biggest gains will require banishing conventional petroleum-based fuel, says the Sustainable Shipping Initiative, a progressive industry ginger group whose members include cruise lines and commodities shipping lines. Innovations ranging from biofuels to liquefied natural gas (LNG), nuclear reactors to sails to catch the wind, and hydrogen to solar panels have been proposed.
Each has its benefits and drawbacks, and nobody is putting all their money on one solution. Biofuels are problematic because they take land to grow, though specially engineered crops such as algae could change that, says the ITF. While electric engines already operate on some short ferry journeys, the sheer weight and space taken up by batteries on oceangoing ships make them unviable until there are breakthroughs in lithium-ion batteries. Solar power can only augment other power sources.
One innovation already underway is converting ships to run on LNG. There are already more than a hundred LNG-fuelled ships globally. A new generation of giant cruise ships powered this way and carrying up to 7,000 passengers will be launched by MSC Cruises starting in 2022. Some LNG ships claim a reduction in CO2 emissions of 15%, though that depends crucially on keeping leakage of the greenhouse gas methane to a minimum in ships and bunkers.
The first LNG-powered cruise ship is the Viking Grace, operating between Finland and Sweden. This vessel has another claim to fame. As of this April it also boasts the first ship-based “rotor sail” to capture power from the wind. Rotor sails have a large spinning cylinder amidships. Wind hitting the rotor creates a vertical force that can be used to power the ship, a phenomenon known as the Magnus effect. The Viking Line says the extra power will reduce the ship’s CO2 emissions by 900 metric tonnes (1,000 tons) per year.

Policies in individual states matter. CA is a larger economy than any European nation other than Germany. Shouldn't it be disaggregated? Should it's very active work on reductions be noted? It would be nice to see that they are somewhat better than the CO2 emissions of, say, Louisiana.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1525802498000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14173421', u'in_reply_to': u'115564389', u'id': u'115581601', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Here’s a graph of the last 400,000 years of global temperature, CO2 and sea level. http://www.ces.fau.edu/nasa/images/impacts/slr-co2-temp-400000yrs.jpg

BQEND
The graph is from Schwalm et al (2012).
The graph was NOT used by the IPCC for AR5 in either WG1 Chapter 12 (Long-term Climate Change: Projections, Commitments and Irreversibility) or WG2 Chapter 26 (North America).
From WG1 (page 1086) :
BQSTART
Other measures in the literature of future agricultural drought are largely focussed on the Palmer Drought Severity Index (Wehner et al., 2011; Schwalm et al., 2012; Dai, 2013) and project ‘extreme’ drought as the normal climatological state by the end of the 21st century under the high emission scenarios in many mid-latitude locations. However, this measure of agricultural drought has been criticized as overly sensitive to increased temperatures due to a simplified soil moisture model (Hoerling et al., 2012).
BQEND

BQSTART
A question with a false, disputed, or question-begging presupposition.
BQEND
BQSTART
A "loaded question", like a loaded gun, is a dangerous thing. A loaded question is a question with a false or questionable presupposition, and it is "loaded" with that presumption. The question "Have you stopped beating your wife?" presupposes that you have beaten your wife prior to its asking, as well as that you have a wife. If you are unmarried, or have never beaten your wife, then the question is loaded.
BQEND
http://www.fallacyfiles.org/loadques.html
Your question is a logical fallacy, it assumes that the article is unbalanced.

description: Dana Nuccitelli: It’s global warming that will hurt the economy in red states, not a carbon tax.
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Dana Nuccitelli: It’s global warming that will hurt the economy in red states, not a carbon tax.
og_fields.og:title: Global warming will depress economic growth in Trump country | Dana Nuccitelli
text:
A working paper recently published by the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond concludes that global warming could significantly slow economic growth in the US. 
Specifically, rising summertime temperatures in the hottest states will curb economic growth. And the states with the hottest summertime temperatures are all located in the South: Florida, Louisiana, Texas, Mississippi, Oklahoma, Alabama, Georgia, South Carolina, Arkansas, and Arizona. All of these states voted for Donald Trump in 2016.
This paper is consistent with a 2015 Nature study that found an optimal temperature range for economic activity. Economies thrive in regions with an average temperature of around 14°C (57°F). Developed countries like the US, Japan, and much of Europe happen to be near that ideal temperature, but continued global warming will shift their climates away from the sweet spot and slow economic growth. The question is, by how much?
The new working paper concludes that if we meet the Paris target of staying below 2°C global warming, US economic growth will only slow by about 5 to 10%. On our current path, including climate policies implemented to date (which would lead to 3–3.5°C global warming by 2100), US economic growth would slow by about 10 to 20%. In a higher carbon pollution scenario (4°C global warming by 2100), US economic growth would slow by about 12 to 25% due to hotter temperatures alone.
House Majority Whip Steve Scalise, who represents Louisiana (the second-hottest state), recently introduced a new anti-carbon tax House Resolution. Scalise introduced similar Resolutions in 2013 with 155 co-sponsors (154 Republicans and 1 Democrat) and in 2015 with 82 co-sponsors (all Republicans). The latest version currently only has one co-sponsor, but more will undoubtedly sign on. All three versions of the Resolution include text claiming, “a carbon tax will lead to less economic growth.”
As the economics research shows, failing to curb global warming will certainly lead to less economic growth. Climate policies could hamper economic growth, but legislation can be crafted to address that concern. 
For example, as Citizens’ Climate Lobby notes in its point-by-point response to the Scalise Resolution, an economic analysis of the group’s proposed revenue-neutral carbon tax policy found that it would modestly spur economic growth (increasing national GDP by $80 to 90bn per year). With this particular policy, 100% of the carbon tax revenue is returned equally to households, and for a majority of Americans, this more than offsets their increased costs. As a result, real disposable income rises, and Americans spend that money, spurring economic growth.
In short, failing to implement climate policies will certainly slow economic growth, especially in hot, red, southern states. A carbon tax, if crafted smartly, could modestly spur economic growth. Blind opposition to carbon taxes is simply bad for the economy and especially bad for Trump voters.
While the Federal Reserve paper focused on the US economy, developing countries will be made much worse off by climate change. Many third world countries are located closer to the equator, where temperatures are already hotter than the temperature sweet spot identified in the 2015 Nature study. A new paper published last week in Science Advances also found that these poorer tropical countries will experience bigger temperature swings in a hotter world. Because of this combination of hot temperatures with bigger swings in countries with fewer resources available to adapt, these poorer nations are the most vulnerable to climate change impacts.
This is a key moral and ethical dilemma posed by global warming: as an important 2011 study concluded, the countries that have contributed the least to the problem are the most vulnerable to its consequences. Meanwhile, wealthy countries are already lagging behind their promised financial aid to help poor countries deal with climate change.
When evaluating climate policies, it’s important to compare the outcomes to the correct baseline. In a world without a carbon tax or other efforts to tackle climate change, temperatures will continue to rise, which will slow economic growth. That’s the baseline against which climate policies need to be compared.
Thus, even if a carbon tax were to slow economic growth, the question is whether it would slow more or less than in the hotter world without the carbon tax. That largely depends on what the rest of the world does, since the US is just one country representing about 14% of global greenhouse gas emissions. But the rest of the world has agreed to try and limit global warming to 2°C in the Paris climate accords – the US is the only country whose leaders are stupid enough to reject that agreement.
Rejecting climate policies like a carbon tax will ensure that the world misses the Paris targets, resulting in slower economic growth. This will particularly hurt poorer countries and Trump’s base in the South. The Federal Reserve Bank paper notes that these states are already among the least developed in the US, based on the Human Development Index. This means that they already have the weakest economies in the US, and failing to take steps to slow global warming will just hamper their economic growth further yet.
In short, if Trump, Scalise, and the rest of the Republican Party want to prevent slowed economic growth in red states, they should be trying to craft an optimal carbon tax, not blindly rejecting the idea outright.

[{u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'The article you have linked from Science Advances is worth reading and even though it is limited to the area around the Ross Ice shelf, it does discuss geothermal heat and its effects on the ice streams and the pools of underwater ice. I should have checked this earlier as, not surprisingly, the Ross Ice shelf is the very area that Walsunda and I were discussing. Mt Erebus and all that. So in one sense it is not "new" (not even in 2015) since the volcano was seen by James Ross in 1841. The article attributes all the local melting in the area to geothermal forces. This cannot be extended to the West Antarctic in general but it is still an interesting article. I wonder also about the outlet Petermannn glacier which often begins melting out before other places on Greenland. 
I would suggest that much of the accumulation of meltwater at glacial bases is the result of moulins where water spirals down from the surface but this does not in any way discredit studies of subsurface lakes beneath the ice. It's not an "either/or" equation but a "both/and" one.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526407859000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3684556', u'in_reply_to': u'115743455', u'id': u'115854738', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526391191000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'115720588', u'id': u'115843581', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'In case anybody is still wondering how Trump means to monitor CO2, Here is a comment from today's news:
"NASA's Carbon Monitoring System (CMS), a $10-million-a-year research line, has helped stitch together observations of sources and sinks into high-resolution models of the planet's flows of carbon. Now, President Donald Trump's administration has quietly killed the CMS, Science has learned.
The move jeopardizes plans to verify the national emission cuts agreed to in the Paris climate accords, says Kelly Sims Gallagher, director of Tufts University's Center for International Environment and Resource Policy in Medford, Massachusetts. "If you cannot measure emissions reductions, you cannot be confident that countries are adhering to the agreement," she says. Canceling the CMS "is a grave mistake," she adds." You are either unable to read, or suffer from some attention span problem.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526297676000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3684556', u'in_reply_to': u'115776554', u'id': u'115793308', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'I can't be bothered to wade though another of your attempts to reinterpret my words. Basically I am aware of various causes of warming effects on the climate. These include cyclical events and more unusual ones. The Milankovitch cycles for example are long term events and other cyclical matters such as the annual seasons, diurnal effects, ~11 year solar cycles and the cycle of El Nino/La Nina warming. 
None of these events are sufficient to act as "causes" for accelerating global warming. You are barking up the tree. Your attempts to cut and paste me into the ground are dull as dish water.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526297441000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3684556', u'in_reply_to': u'115772981', u'id': u'115793092', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'loco_p_man', u'text': u'BQSTART
there is medium confidence that it would not exceed several tenths of a meter of sea level rise during the 21st century.

We should not forget that even the scientific consensus figures carry significant implications for many cities and low-lying countries and islands. Say 30 cm of rise by the end of the century - it's not being "alarmist" to say that this would cause a lot of problems.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526286276000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'this', u'effect': u'a lot of problems'}], u'author_id': u'13126382', u'in_reply_to': u'115767430', u'id': u'115783099', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID2310987', u'text': u'BQSTART
I won`t bother posting the links because you will ignore them in any case,
BQEND
Ironic as you've ignored what the lead author of a study you linked to said...
BQSTART
Lead author Andrew Fisher, professor of Earth and planetary sciences at UC Santa Cruz, emphasized that the geothermal heating reported in this study does not explain the alarming loss of ice from West Antarctica that has been documented by other researchers. "The ice sheet developed and evolved with the geothermal heat flux coming up from below—it's part of the system. But this could help explain why the ice sheet is so unstable. When you add the effects of global warming, things can start to change quickly," he said.
BQEND
Which is pretty well what everyone has been telling you. The ice sheet developed and evolved with this heat source, it doesn't explain the recent alarming loss of ice but its not good news when you have this heat source in addition to rising temperatures.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526283149000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"you will ignore them in any case bqend ironic as you 've ignored what the lead author of a study you linked to said", u'effect': u'bqstart i won`t bother posting the links'}], u'author_id': u'2515806', u'in_reply_to': u'115772981', u'id': u'115780975', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'I have repeated the difference between volcanic activity and geothermal heat flux - two things which you have confused. I have also repeated in more detail quoting from the sources you used the difference between localised and basin wide levels of geothermal heat flux which seems to be at heart of your confusion behind your musings as to the contribution of geothermal heat to overall glacial ice melting in Antarctica. I know what I know but don't know how much you know. 
As a geologist with a friend who has climbed Mt Erebus I accept the reality of geothermal heat in small parts of Antarctica as occurs in other volcanic provinces but am realistic to the very small extent of any contribution to overall Antarctic glacial melting from that source as are all the papers you have linked to. As opinion has no place in a scientific discussion where statements must be based on evidence, it's unreasonable to expect me to acknowledge what you have opined.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526280079000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'115776554', u'id': u'115779427', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Anthonyhu', u'text': u'I`m not sure why you are taking the line of repeating what we already know along with excerpts from links supplied.
You seem to be accepting of geothermal and volcanic heat under parts of Antarctica without admitting that contribution to melting from "below" or the fact as I originally opined what the contribution may be and the refusal of an acknowledgement thereof.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526266993000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17407909', u'in_reply_to': u'115775004', u'id': u'115776554', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JoeyBumpkin', u'text': u'Well don’t that beat allI hear the White House is jumpin’ for joy.The plan is to stall global warming until it’s ready to pop. Then they’re going to grant polar cap iceberg towing permits to three of Mr T’s favored confidents. Big money in Global Warming, now “leaning in” (to the right)', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526261418000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100397338', u'id': u'115775482', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'So we were never in danger of an imminent ice age or glacial period but we now face the prospect of global warming beyond the Holocene maximum. That is beyond the temperature of the beginning of widespread agriculture.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526259941000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'115652634', u'id': u'115775178', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'If atmospheric CO2 had remained at 280 ppm the next ice age would not have occurred for another 50,000 years. With CO2 now in excess of 400 ppm it may be cancelled.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526259232000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'115648897', u'id': u'115775038', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'Geothermal heat flux and volcanic activity are not the same thing as discussed previously. Though an rise in the former can be a warning of an increased possibility of the latter. Average geothermal heat worldwide is about 60 mW/square metre. as your quote says, the average for West Antartica is 105 + or - 13 mW/m2, which is not that much more. Rates of 285 + or - 80 mW/m2 are localised as occurs in most other volcanic provinces.
Much greater melting of ice occurs along the coast where glaciers are grounded below and in contact with the now warmer Southern Ocean waters at depth. The subglacial lakes and canal/streamways provide a lubricant that allows the glacier to move toward the sea. This seaward movement can only occur in rimmed a glacial basin if melting at the foot of the glacier removes the blocking foot.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526259021000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'115743455', u'id': u'115775004', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'And of course SLR may get much worse in the 22 century, it all depends on the big question mark of when the WAIS starts to go in earnest.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526258116000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'115767430', u'id': u'115774785', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'In Australia as a Queenslander I regard myself as a northerner. The southern tip of Tasmania is at about the same latitude as Tasmania while the southern tip of the mainland is at the same latitude as Granada in Spain. On the southern coasts of Tasmania, South Australia and Western Australia you can look and know there's nothing but ocean between you and Antarctica. President Emmanuel Macron recently described Australian PM's wife Lucy Turnbull as "delicious". On an ice floe, Leopard Seals look like long giant slugs but in water they're incredibly graceful.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526257216000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'115753184', u'id': u'115774552', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Anthonyhu', u'text': u'In your ongoing attempts to ignore other causes of warming and you are by far not alone in this you still obfuscate and pretend you don`t know what I`m talking about.
BQSTART
the geothermal conditions on Antarctica have not been reported to be different from usual and in any case would not be sufficient to cause the ice loss on Antarctica.
BQEND
At no point did I argue this is what I said was:
BQSTART
It would be interesting to know how much of the melting is related.
BQEND
 You say:
BQSTART
the geothermal conditions on Antarctica have not been reported to be different from usual and in any case would not be sufficient to cause the ice loss on Antarctica. The particular subject you mentioned; geothermal effects on glaciers is well known.
BQEND That is your construct presented without proof, your considered opinion of the study results, I think I`ll take the latter and once again if you read the links I presented you would not even make that statement.
e.g.
BQSTART
Together, these observations provide strong evidence for ongoing magmatic activity and demonstrate that volcanism continues to migrate southwards along the Executive Committee Range.
BQEND and

BQSTART
The geothermal heat flux is a critical thermal boundary condition that influences the melting, flow, and mass balance of ice sheets, but measurements of this parameter are difficult to make in ice-covered regions.
BQEND and
BQSTART
Uncertainty in the amount and spatial pattern of geothermal flux and melting beneath this glacier is a major limitation in predicting its future behavior and sea level contribution.

That probably depends on the definition of "all"! But The Royal Society report assessing the science published since AR5 stated:
How might this affect the IPCC statement? With the exception of one prominent study that projects the loss of most West Antarctic ice by 2500 under even moderate warming scenarios, other recent research is still broadly consistent with the AR5 assessment that marine ice sheet instability contribution to sea level rise will “not exceed several tenths of a meter” by 2100. Thus the AR5 projections still represent current understanding, although suggestions that the contribution could be greater than was previously assessed need further evaluation. Quantitative uncertainties, reflected in the spread of results from recent studies, reinforce the need for better understanding of the processes leading to ice shelf and ice sheet retreat. It is moreover virtually certain that sea level rise will continue for many centuries. In a climate as warm as those projected in many models for 2100 and beyond under high emissions scenarios, large parts of both ice sheets would be lost over millennia, leaving sea level many metres higher than present.
https://royalsociety.org/~/media/policy/Publications/2017/27-11-2017-Climate-change-updates-report.pdf
I think that society as a whole is ill-equipped to deal with a slow motion car crash, so yes: we're being too complacent.

Its constant-temperature melting does absorb thermal energy, but it melts only because global warming has added thermal energy to its environment.
Once the ice has gone, its absence reduces the reflectivity of it former location, thus increasing further the earth's retention of oncoming solar radiation and accelerating the rate of glo all warming.
That's one grave issue for the whole globe. A slightly more localised issue will be, as addressed in the article, the loss of the effect of saline water freezing onto existing circim-polar sub-zero C sea ice, which by crystallising out some of the water generates a more saline, and thus more dense high-salinity liquid fraction which then sinks down nto the ocean depths and flows slowly back towards the Gulf of Mexico. That returning high-salt, dense and deep current is a driver of the warm surface counter-current we call the Gulf Stream. And if we no longer have a sufficiently cold arctic to drive the fractional crystallisation on which it depends, then the Warm Gulf Stream may die. OK?', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526237934000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'only global warming has added thermal energy to its environment', u'effect': u'it melts'}], u'author_id': u'14769888', u'in_reply_to': u'115715536', u'id': u'115766329', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'quietreason', u'text': u'A good point. The problem with dykes, sea walls and movable dams such as the UK's Thames barrier is their extreme sensitivity to the combined effects of sea level and wave height.
While sea levels are rising at a seemingly modest 3mm/year that rate of rise is itself accelerating. And all indications are that future events resulting from global warming will induce step change increases in that rate.
When a storm causes a few wave peaks to overtop a barrier, that is rarely a problem as it is only the wave tips, and only a few of them. As the mean sea level rises, and/or the wave heights rise due to increasing storm intensities, the amount and frequency by which those waves overtop those walls also rise, as does the total length of that part of each wave which overtops the wall.
Each of these factors greatly increases the total influx per unit length of sea wall. Which means that the rate of seawater influx over the wall rises dramatically,out of all proportion to the increase in sea level and/or storm intensity.
And this is why, as you say, our largest cities, and extensive coastal plains (which form much of our habitable and arable lands), are likely to be suddenly and irrecoverably inundated in the uncomfortably near future.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526226543000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'a storm', u'effect': u'a few wave peaks to overtop a barrier'}, {u'cause': u'increasing storm intensities', u'effect': u'the wave heights rise'}], u'author_id': u'14769888', u'in_reply_to': u'115726177', u'id': u'115759914', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'Try rereading my remarks instead of just placatively reposting them in your own context. https://phys.org/news/2015-07-surprisingly-high-geothermal-beneath-west.html', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526196733000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2515806', u'in_reply_to': u'115743455', u'id': u'115746812', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Anthonyhu', u'text': u'Nice you have moved away from the Ad hominem into the world of "real discussion" well done.I refer you to my previous links which you did not read, in retrospect I should have made the distinction between geothermal and volcanic although I expected most would be aware the second will not happen without the first. BQSTART
The geothermal heat flux is a critical thermal boundary condition that influences the melting, flow, and mass balance of ice sheets, but measurements of this parameter are difficult to make in ice-covered regions. We re- port the first direct measurement of geothermal heat flux into the base of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS), below Subglacial Lake Whillans, determined from the thermal gradient and the thermal conductivity of sedi- ment under the lake. The heat flux at this site is 285 ± 80 mW/m2, significantly higher than the continental and regional averages estimated for this site using regional geophysical and glaciological models. Independent tem- perature measurements in the ice indicate an upward heat flux through the WAIS of 105 ± 13 mW/m2. The difference between these heat flux values could contribute to basal melting and/or be advected from Subglacial Lake Whillans by flowing water. The high geothermal heat flux may help to explain why ice streams and subglacial lakes are so abundant and dynamic in this region.
BQEND

For more detail see our FAQs.', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526187111000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"it did n't abide by our community standards", u'effect': u'this comment was removed by a moderator'}], u'author_id': u'17407909', u'in_reply_to': u'115709718', u'id': u'115743207', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'As an Australian child growing up in the 1950s, I learnt about Scott's ill-fated expedition in primary school. Tragic stories of explorers perishing in blizzards or in either the Australian deserts (Burke and Wills) or rainforests (Kennedy) were a feature of the school syllabus in those days. Later as a young person working in science and combining that with adventure a number of friends and colleagues spent time on various Antarctic and sub-Antarctic bases coming back with stories and beautiful photographs.
Scott's expedition was part of the British Antarctic expedition which took place from 1910 to 1913, overlapping with the Australian from 1911-1914 which was led by Australian Geologist Douglas Mawson who when on Shsckleton's 1907-09 expedition had been in the first party to climb Mt Erebus. Like the roughly concurrent British expedition Mawson's expedition made significant discoveries in geology, glaciology and terrestrial biology as well as charting 3,200 km of coastline.
A joint British, Australian (and) New Zealand Antarctic research expedition in 1929-31, also led by Mawson has been described as an "Acquisitive exploratory expedition with Mawson making proclamations of British sovereignty over Antarctic lands at each of his five landfalls"; but it also produced 13 volumes of reports on geology, oceanography, meteorology, terrestrial magnetism, zoology and botany between 1935 and 1975. British sovereignty was later ceded to Australia. In the first half of the twentieth British and Australian sovereignty were regarded as much the same.
Mawson lobbied for the establishment of a permanent Australian Antarctic base which was established in 21958 and bears his name. My three friends spent various periods of time in Antarctica and the sub-Antarctic Islands.
One a botanist and British citizen was director of the British South Georgia base at the time they captured by the Argentine Navy and held in Buenos Aires. Amid the fervid reports of that war his comment that they were being well treated and fed good Argentine steak was welcome relief. He brought back slides of sled dogs, wonderful scenery and entire plant ecosystems minus vascular plants.
One an engineer who overwintered at the Australian base also brought back wonderful slides of dogs, scenery, wildlife and weather. He climbed Mt Erebus and undertook a long motorised overland seismic line journey.
The third, 20 years my senior had researched penguins in the early days of the Antarctic Division when Mawson was still alive. Apparently the old blokes party trick at fairly flash gatherings was to talk about and imitate the mating call of the male Leopard Seal to which his wife would answer "You called dear?". When under the water, Leopard Seals are truly magnificent animals.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526182819000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'115721134', u'id': u'115742501', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'So what would you ask a glacialogist, or climate scientist working in the cryosphere?

I not planning for a zombi apocalypse - Im not planning for the 'Day after Tomorrow' but are we all being a little too complacent?', u'recommendation_count': u'10', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526174795000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4738374', u'id': u'115741164', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glacier', u'text': u'This is a bit unfair. 
Remember that the zero dimensional climate models (which is like all models - just physics) were asked how black-body radiation is affected by having and "imbrella". James Hansen did his early years on studying this for other planets at NASA. 
Slowly models became 1 dimensional, and even 2 and 3 dimensional. 
But at core, they all did a really good job because of how they solve the zero or one-dimensional equations known in the 19th century when it comes to planetary accumulation of heat. 
Remember, as planet, the mean global temperature still is a zero-dimensional problem of that black body. 
Those equations can of course not solve the dynamics of space (and as such - glaciers are space as function of dynamics of incoming and outgoing solar radiation). These original models can not solve the more 3-dimentional equations of why both the ocean and atmosphere move heat from equator to the poles either. 
Fact is that models does a fantastic job in solving the energy balance of our planet - because that is a zero order problem. What models do less than fantastic is to simulate the 3 dimensional energy transport as it moves through the 4th dimension of space and interact on the way. 
Modellers are tied in by the coastline problem (goggle it) 
It is a resolution problem. 
This is important because models are not "set up" for something.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526171267000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that is a zero order problem', u'effect': u'that models does a fantastic job in solving the energy balance of our planet'}, {u'cause': u'models are not set up for', u'effect': u'this is important'}], u'author_id': u'4706143', u'in_reply_to': u'115729548', u'id': u'115740281', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bruce Morgan Williams', u'text': u'The models were never set up to account for all the positive feedbacks that have been discovered over the last decade or two. The probability that they grossly underestimate warming is extremely high.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526155217000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11287291', u'id': u'115729548', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Sea level rise can be lulling at the current rate of around 3mm per year or a foot per century.

So many of our largest cities won’t go slowly with the drip, drip, drip of sea level rise, but abruptly in catastrophic storms.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526149524000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'id': u'115726177', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Regarding that reverse incline, the Totten Glacier in East Antarctica, which drains more ice than the entire West Antarctic, has about 50 km to retreat on a prograde bed before it turns retrograde, or reverse sloped, and in the words of Eric Rignot, “all hell breaks loose.”', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526139600000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'115721233', u'id': u'115722143', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'KingInYellow', u'text': u'An interesting study that is in line with all the others, an underlying warming sea water melting the ice.

False No, NASA Antarctica study didn’t discredit climate change science By Amy Sherman on Monday, November 20th, 2017 at 1:22 p.m. 
The public has been misled by climate change advocates about the real reason behind the melting of Antarctica’s western ice sheet, claims the website American News.
Facebook users flagged the post as being potentially misleading, as part of the social network’s efforts to combat fake news. We emailed American News but did not get a reply.
The American News story refers to a real study by NASA, but the headline falsely suggests that the study debunks climate change advocates. A NASA scientist involved in the study told us the headline is inaccurate.
Here’s the real story: On Nov. 7, NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., issued a summary of the study about the heat source under West Antarctica. The paper, "Influence of a West Antarctic mantle plume on ice sheet basal conditions," was published in the Journal of Geophysical Research: Solid Earth.
The heat source isn’t new or increasing, but may help explain why the ice sheet collapsed so rapidly in an earlier area of climate change and remains unstable.
Some 30 years ago, a scientist at the University of Colorado Denver suggested that heat from a mantle plume under Marie Byrd Land might explain regional volcanic activity and a topographic dome feature, NASA wrote. Recent seismic imaging has supported this concept.
 
"At the end of the last ice age around 11,000 years ago, the ice sheet went through a period of rapid, sustained ice loss when changes in global weather patterns and rising sea levels pushed warm water closer to the ice sheet -- just as is happening today," NASA said.
Erik Ivins, a scientist and the second author on the study, told PolitiFact that the study didn’t address climate change.
"The study itself is about steady state conditions that would exist at the bottom of the ice sheet for many many millions of years," he said. "We think of climate change as occurring 10 years, 100 years, maybe 500 years -- our study has nothing to do with those time scales."
The NASA study is about the bottom of the ice sheet. Climate change has had an impact on the top of the ice sheet. Warmer ocean waters intruding on the ice shelf causes the ice shelves to break up. When grounded ice sheets exit the land and go into the water that causes sea level rise
"This study doesn’t discredit that," he says. "Nothing in our paper has anything to do with climate change."
BQEND

British and Australian Antarctic made use of sledge dogs until late into last century. From 1889 to 1994 sledge dogs were used in Antarctica by explorers and scientists. When Mawson base was established in the 1950's a breeding pack of sledge was an important part of the operation. The last Antarctic sledge dogs were removed from the continent in 1994 due to fears of Distemper spreading to Antarctic seals. They were shipped to Hobart,quarantined, then flown to Los Angeles for a road trip to Minnesota where they work as sledge dogs and continue the breed. The next year a few of the original Antarctic dogs took a sledge to the North Pole.

He said that’s maybe not the best case, it’s not the worst case.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526070100000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'115701144', u'id': u'115701984', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glacier', u'text': u'Here is news of the sensitivity of our planet that should worry us: 
I think even deniers know that ice-ages are paced by cycles in the Earth orbit that cause small changes to how much, and at which latitudes and seasons we receive peak solar insolation here on Earth. These are marginal changes, but our internal dynamics amply it to the extent that we get sea-level changes by 10 meters per 1000 year (as average trend). 
Now, Ever since Milancowich a century ago, we have known that when we solve the equations, there is also a weak c. 400,000 harmonic going on. Mainly caused by our big planets tugging on our orbit. 
But we only had around 2.5 million years of recent ice-age signals to trace - so that provide only 6 repetitions of a harmonic - and that is not enough (also because the Plio Pleistocene also changed own harmonics internally on our planet around a million years ago) 
So - last week came results from rock cores going hundreds of millions of years back. 
And here is the scary news - that tiny tiny amount of solar energy that these almost half a million year wobbles create by the solar system is fixed in the rocks under us - so much that science can measure it. 
https://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2018-05/teia-iar050418.php
It is important to remember that GHG gasses can at zero order be considered as external (like orbital changes) instead of internal (like El Nino variations). 
And when stuff happening hundreds of million years ago - in the age of dinosaurs pick up this orbital signal - we should be seriously conserned as we now provide change in our energy balance of several Watt per square meters - within time-scales measured in decades. 
I understand that deniers still talking about hockey-gate think that paleoclimate is there to prove the AGW hypothesis. This is wrong. Paleoclimate exists to provide long time-series and sensitivity information. 
For those who think paleoclimate is slave of models - rethink that. It is paleoclimate that has continously been telling the modellers involved in IPCC that the estimates grossly underestimate the risk of rapid degliaction (models are nowhere near to simulate what reality has shown to be facts). Models do well with steady state simulations (even last glacial maximum conditions and Eocene conditions that paleoclimate provides for them as test-bench mean conditions - but when it comes calculate transitions - they are sadly bad at that even though they are getting better. 
That they are doing bad is not the fault of bad understanding of physics - it is limited by how many Flops the biggest computers in the world can do. 
Of course a climate model from 1990 or 2010 could not predict the sub-glacial energy transfer pathways. Paleoclimate studies could not either. 
But science can know that there are some serious issues with this issue - and with the balmy 3 degree warmer planet they promise us by on purpose mixing up the feedback sensitivity of 2xCO2 with some idea that it can not be more than 3 degrees whatever we do as their private sensitivity (or giving carbon-only sensitivity). 
I have said this before, science is running after the pace of change. 
The nation of USA like that since Trump canceled the NASA's Carbon Monitoring System (CMS)
http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2018/05/trump-white-house-quietly-cancels-nasa-research-verifying-greenhouse-gas-cuts
It saved the US a NASA post costing 10 million dollars a year. Because there is much more profit to be made in pretending one move change way faster than science can keep up with. 
I bet it will be popular to chose "harakiri" well in advance of having to see own grandchildren in eyes and explain.', u'recommendation_count': u'10', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526067542000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u'small changes to how much at which latitudes and seasons'}, {u'cause': u'our big planets tugging on our orbit', u'effect': None}, {u'cause': u'also the plio pleistocene also changed own harmonics internally on our planet around a million years ago', u'effect': u'and that is not enough'}], u'author_id': u'4706143', u'id': u'115701144', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DennisHorne', u'text': u'I've seen various numbers but this site reckons 90% fresh water on the surface is held in the Antarctic ice sheet:https://www.sciencedaily.com/terms/antarctic_ice_sheet.htm', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526066493000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4446531', u'in_reply_to': u'115691535', u'id': u'115700747', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Thanks for the link. I’ve been curious to see what more research would turn up. Even without the boulder evidence, it seems the increased horizontal temperature gradient between parts of the N Atlantic caused by a shutdown of the AMOC would drive bigger storms. Look at the 30 percent increase in the strength of the Southern Ocean westerly winds since the 80s from this effect.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526057133000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'a shutdown of the amoc', u'effect': u'the increased horizontal temperature gradient between parts of the n atlantic'}], u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'115693527', u'id': u'115696227', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'razorclam', u'text': u'I think what worries me most of all, and it obviously worries many others, is that for such incredible volumes of ice to be melting at this speed means the oceanic-atmospheric system is already so overloaded with human added greenhouse gasses that a massive amount of melting and sea level rise, and intense storms, spread of diseases, droughts, mega-fires, mass extinctions and so on and on... are already "baked-in". The debate that is still happening despite these conditions continues to become more surreal with each passing day.
I mean the environmental progress I have observed in the last ~40 years (when many environmental issues really started to get wide public airing) has been beyond pitiful. What does this say about our dominant value systems ability to recognize and address environmental health?
It seems that many are waiting for technological/market or theological miracle instead of doing the things we know will work.
 Let's face it if we want to maintain anything even remotely resembling life-as-we-know-it we are simply going to have use a great deal less energy; anything short of this is just going to prolong the slide a little longer. 
This idea, an idea so widespread, dominant, and reinforced that it is very rarely questioned in public, that we are going to have to match (and then greatly exceed in the coming decades) the amount of energy we are now generating largely with fossil carbon with renewables is an environmental non-starter, we have lost before we are even on the field with this kind of thinking. 
If you understand the physics of energy and the flow of energy through the living world we call ecology and you are able to include cruial contextual elements of time and space (natural history/ecology/environmental history) then you understand that we are very limited when it comes to options that will actually work within the very small window of opportunity that we have left.
 I know this flies directly in the face of capitalist/consumerist/progress dogma and I know that this change is not likely to happen; how very sad. 
We can live lives in which we are happier and more content while owning less and using less, but to do so we will have to have an honest look at what things are truly most important to us and then realize that these things are being severely threatened from all sides.
To avoid the urge, a very understandable urge, to just give up we also have to try to break out of the dichotomous thinking that is so ingrained and realize that although we cannot avoid many horrible results from the global environmental crisis that the range of severity of potential outcomes is truly a huge.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1526056019000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4615682', u'id': u'115695408', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'The superstorm idea was largely based on ideas about the power needed to move very large boulders, but there have been recent incidents of very large boulders moved by 'ordinary' big storms, such as
