description: On the ABC, the gender gap, climate change and wage growth, the Liberals pretend to care while making sure nothing changes
og_fields.og:description: On the ABC, the gender gap, climate change and wage growth, the Liberals pretend to care while making sure nothing changes
og_fields.og:title: All care, no policy: Liberal party pretenders exposed | Greg Jericho
text:
It probably should be no surprise that last night’s royal wedding became part of the political debate this week. But the criticism by government members highlighted yet again the Liberal party’s policy of pretending to care about something while simultaneously doing everything to work against it.
Peter Dutton and Tasmanian senator Eric Abetz bought into the issue of the ABC’s coverage of the royal wedding off the back of erroneous reporting in News Corp papers suggesting the ABC had flown hosts Annabel Crabb and Jeremy Fernandez to London in business class. Abetz, who is never one to miss an opportunity to slight the ABC, echoed Dutton’s thoughts when he suggested he would “would like to see the justification for flying those two over when there is a crew permanently in London”.
It is the standard operating procedure of the Liberal party: cut funding to the ABC that in effect is designed to ensure it struggles to do a professional job, then either criticise it for not being up to scratch or, when it does something professionally, criticise it for wasting money.
It’s the cannot-win argument. Had the ABC taken the cheaper option, Abetz and his ilk would have screamed about how the ABC disrespected the monarchy and Australians by not treating the event with the appropriate level of attention.
But really, all this talk about the ABC from Abetz and Dutton is just a continuation of the long run of the Liberal party being disingenuously concerned about things it is actively against.
Take the gender ​gap in parliament. There are a lot of furrowed brows within the Liberal party at the moment after the ​ dumping of frontbencher Jane Prentice as a candidate at the next election, and challenges to Victorian senator Jane Hume and NSW MP Ann Sudmalis, have made it rather all too clear just how few women they have in the parliament.
Only 13 of the 76 Liberal party MPs are women – rather a long way from its target of having 50% of women contesting “winnable seats” by 2025.
And yet, rather than introducing a quota to achieve this target, which has been proven to work (as the ALP has done and which now has women accounting for 47% of its MPs), it has instead chosen to throw money at the problem.
Kelly O’Dwyer has established a fund to help financially support ​female candidates. And while no doubt the aim is good, even this very market-based option has been attacked by those within the Liberal party.
Demonstrating the strong inherent bias against doing anything to improve the gender gap, ​ Eric Abetz (yes, once again) suggested the fund was not “necessarily consistent with the Liberal philosophy”.
Actually the fund is very much in keeping with that philosophy – it will do nothing to overcome the systemic bias against women but it looks like they’re trying to do something about it.
We get a policy that barely looks like they’re trying to achieve something and which is designed not to achieve its aim
It’s much like their position on climate change.
Many in the Liberal party wish to do nothing about it, and those who do are mostly content to do something that looks like something while studiously avoiding the one solution that has been shown to work.
The latest greenhouse gas emissions data released by the Department of Environment last week showed that during the carbon price period emissions continually fell, and since its end they have continually risen.
And yet Malcolm Turnbull and Josh Frydenberg – in the spirit of the Liberal party philosophy – have to come up with a policy to reduce greenhouse gas emissions that avoids not just putting a price on carbon but even looking like doing so. Thus we get a policy that barely even looks like they’re trying to achieve something and which is clearly designed not to achieve its aim.
And of course, economic policy is not excused from the pretence of care or accompanying lack of policy.
The latest wage growth figures showed yet again that wages have not risen in real terms in the past year. This is a problem for the government because, while the Liberal party has long been a champion of keeping wages growth down in the name of “competitiveness”, its budget is very much in favour of it.
The budget’s predictions for strong income tax growth in 2020-21 and 2021-22 are based on wages growth returning to 3.5%. Were that to occur, the budget predicts real wages would grow by 1% in those years.
And yet how is this to be achieved? Right now the only wages policy is company tax cuts in the hope that increased investment will improve productivity, which will then (eventually) flow through into stronger wage growth.
But in the meantime, the Liberal party has actively sought to reduce workers’ collective bargaining power through increased intervention in union activity, cheered the removal of penalty rates, and strenuously argued against any government intervention that might see a greater increase in the minimum wage.
And add to that their long history of criticism whenever a union either seeks or achieves a decent pay raise.
Back in January 2014, the then minister for employment, Eric Abetz (yes, again), warned that unless businesses stood up to unions’ pay demands, we risked seeing a “wages explosion”. At the time, overall wages were growing at just 2.7% and not one industry had annual wages growth above 3.5%, which is now the target for all wages for three years’ time.
Should wages growth ever actually reach the optimistic levels predicted in the budget, you can bet Liberal party MPs will decry the unions destroying our competitiveness and seek to implement ever more interventionist policy to reduce what power they have left.
And no doubt, in the tradition of the cannot-win argument, they will then criticise unions for failing to deliver for their members.

If we focus purely on transport then the inclusion of a battery on a like for like nature [i.e. a 300 mile range Model S with a luxury ICE] then the embedded energy [and CO2] is at most 50% more. So using CO2 as an indication of energy use [as a neat comparison]So 2 tonnes of CO2 to produce an ICV and 3 tonnes to produce an EV- in lifetimes the EV doing 100,000 miles [i.e. 10 years, the average life expectancy of both EVs and ICVs is 13] - such as a Tesla S will consume about 4,000 kWh [4 MWh] over the year, 40,000 kWh [40 MWh] over its life.
In energy/CO2 terms this from wind would be [using plumb's IPCC link] 12 grams / kWh, and for solar 40 grams/kWh [although the location varies the amount from 8 grams to 80 grams]- 12g/kWh = 1.2kg MWh x 40 is about a half a tonne, and for solar near 2 tonnes.
A petrol or diesel of that size is doing between 100g and 200g a mile x 10,000 miles meaning it is producing 1.5 tonnes a year and 15 tonnes over its life.
The g/km are based on simply the CO2 produced in combustion- However oil requires energy to extract and process so saudi oil is lower in CO2 content because it requires less energy to extract and process, Canadian tarsands is 25% more CO2 because of the processing and extraction inputs. One of the missing pieces of data is the processing cost in energy and CO2 of refining and capex.
Material requirements of renewables and batteries is not an issue yet- there is plenty of lithium, it can be recycled as can cobalt and rare [not rare] earth metals- and the auto makers are gaining energy density by reducing the material content.
And at some point non fossil fuel energy will be producing all the energy to make more wind turbines and solar panels. Steel making is a problem- recycling can be done with electric [and it is a cheaper method] but ore needing the oxygen to be stripped out will always produce CO2 and the need for CCS.
However the point I make is that oil is quickly becoming energy intense as well.On a grid level other forms of storage make sense- like pumped, batteries are great in domestic, business, and transport use, just as laptops are very useful. And it is a challenge- but I'm optimistic.

who is an expert in oceans and climate change, not energy economics.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527258224000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'116222366', u'id': u'116224579', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glennmr', u'text': u'While I agree with most of what you posted—I have posted similar issues related to energy return. It is more than a macro economic issue as the physical limits are an issue for renewables. Money won’t change that equation. 
The energy return and energy density for renewables is just not that good—the higher values for solar and wind do not include storage and that is likely to pull them into the 2:1 level—and possible worse. With the energy density low and high material input due to low energy density, the materials requirement are on the order of 10 times more than old Rankine systems. Lithium batteries still have an energy density of about 50 times less than gas and diesel. That will not change sufficiently. 
In the US, there is about one million MW of installed capacity...for renewables, MIT estimates about 2 to 5 times that capacity is needed to cover the grid with reasonable availability...that is a lot of stuff. 
An additional issue is the materials requirement...such as silver for photo voltaics…lithium for batteries. Thin film requiring tellurium…a total boondoggle at high penetration levels. Neodymium and dysprosium for many wind turbines are all not going to be as plentiful as needed…etc. Recycling batteries is OK, but that is also net negative. Recycling solar panels is difficult due to the diffuse nature of their installation.
http://web.mit.edu/12.000/www/m2016/finalwebsite/index.html
On a good note, MIT is working on a solar thermal PV that has a theoretical efficiency of 80%...they only hit 7% so far, but it is something. The SolarEdge power optimizers utilize a very high efficiency single-stage dc-to-dc converter controlled by custom application specific integrated circuit (ASIC) devices. The power optimizer is typically located immediately adjacent to, or attached directly to, the PV module. In addition to Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) and dc-to-dc conversion the power optimizers provide module level monitoring and a number of safety related functions.

Miners being sensible mined the easy to get to high energy coal first- and then they were forced to spend more time digging out rock, and then forced to switch to lower quality coals- to the point US coal producers were making a loss on the coal they sold and went bankrupt.
Two things are saving the free market from destroying coal completely- very cheap debt and very old power stations. Most of the US has old sub critical power plants.They are cheap to run because they were paid for decades ago and they got a get out clause to allow them not to have clean up their pollution.
In China all new coal power plants are either super critical or ultra supercritical - i.e. they get more energy out of a tonne of coal than subcritical. The US is mainly old plants built before 1990 - and they are inefficient effectively burning 20% coal than they need to- which means the buyers of coal are looking to keep the price super low, and they are the only customer so they can set the price.
By 2050 most of the US coal power station fleet will need replacing.Add to this the huge debt coal mining companies carry- because the buyers have driven down the profits- debt is based on the notion that things will get better and that a return will happen.

There is no “consensus” on EROEI for solar or wind that I have seen and all of those typically published do not include storage.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527275009000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17680035', u'in_reply_to': u'116231931', u'id': u'116235010', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'I don't dispute that renewables do use more materials than fossil fuel power- mainly because fossil fuel power uses million year old stored energy, and nuclear uses billion year old nuclear energy.Likewise the most sensible thing would be to have public transport rather than millions of cars, or one central computer rather than millions of smart phones and pcs.
Recycling of materials only works if the energy input/cost is lower than new resource- for a lot of plastics the need for sorting, collection etc makes it energy intense.your EROI link makes for some interesting reading- but it does set a particular bar that only nuclear [and gas] can cross, and 'buffering' EROI if it is not perfectly suited to instant use.It is an outlier and quite an old one - in the same way a notorious paper took the worst of nuclear and came up with a 1:1 EROI. So I'll stick to the general consensus.As for Mackay- WOHA is an interesting book, it is just a book, it is not a paper.My criticism is more in presenting arguments- for instance if W/M2 is the best way to measure energy generation then nuclear wins. But if we looked at calories to the hectare then sugar cane would win [and no one is suggesting we survive on sugar].
It's a bit like Top Trumps of my youth- the winning card was not always the best bike or car or plane.So for w/M2 it doesn't matter if vast offshore waters are used for energy- they are not being used for much else. And they provide cheap energy [now at £65 MWh], reefs and fish protection areas [and the EROI is very good]. Likewise if a solar roof is similar in price to a tile roof why not have both the protection of a roof and energy- it is not as if the sq metres are being used for anything else.
But my biggest complaint is the final 'can we survive on renewables page' 18- where a staggering 195 kWh per person per day is presented as the challenge for renewables to meet. it includes the current petrol/diesel fuel consumption of 40 kWh [4 ltrs a day per person] air travel, imports etc etc.It may be a really good example of energy intense lifestyle but does not represent the energy generation renewables could provide or our actual needs. If it were 'can nuclear provide our energy needs ?' then 195 kWh per person would mean 300 new nuclear power stations to be built before 2050.We use about 15-20 kWh per person per day [according to Mackay in the ref] And renewables only need to provide that- still a challenge.
And the energy future is not going to be 40 kWh of personal car energy- it will be 10 kWh of EV electrical energy. And we certainly cannot sustain our leaky British homes- meaning heating needs should decline.
You last blog link is our very own post PrismUK's wacky blog- sadly predictable rather than entertaining. [and he is blog mate of Fenbeagle- the climate change denier cartoonist [although his work is actually quite good, pity he wastes his talent].', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527268840000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'mainly fossil fuel power uses million year old stored energy and nuclear uses billion year old nuclear energy', u'effect': u"i do n't dispute that renewables do use more materials than fossil fuel power-"}], u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'116229433', u'id': u'116231931', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'I think few think that solar is the magic bullet or batteries will save the world- so to go back to the OP

BQSTART
Someone posted about a dump truck having a 4.5 tonne battery which stored about 700kw-hrs of energy...that is the equivalent of about 18 gallons of diesel.
BQEND
 18 gallons of diesel at 9 kWh per litre = 70 ltrs x 10= 700kWh -correct, but a diesel engine is rubbish in energy use terms with 75% being wasted in heat etc- a 700 kWh EV battery [and 200 kW motor] is closer to 80 gallons in real use terms.
Take an average 20 tonne excavator- it uses a 90 kW diesel engine to run the hydraulics. In a long 10 hr working day the fuel consumption is around 200 litres. i.e. 2 MWh- for an EV with no conversion losses from heat etc that is just 500 kWhThe Tesla 100 kWh battery weighs just under 600 kg, so total weight is 3 tonnes

cost savings are huge- 200 ltrs at 65p ltr are £130 - the recharge cost of 500 +10% max charge loss for fast charging- at 8p kWh = £40and [according to fleet operators of buses] a 40%-50% saving in maintenance.The big factor is cost- batteries are around the $200 kWh, so we need to wait another few years to see $100 kWh. The biggest JCB 360 excavator [tracked back hoe] at 40 tonnes uses just a 200 kW motor [the Tesla S has a 300 kW motor]- to drive hydraulics, it has several tonnes of counter weights. So battery weight is no problem, power is no problem, range is no problem [and everything from farm to construction could have cartridge batteries] and they tend to spend their nights in a depot.Farmers are reliant on cheap energy- so having a battery charging from solar [lined along boundaries or on barns etc] and a battery similar to hand power tools- i.e. one size fits all, means a huge input cost is eliminated.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527172966000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'116150382', u'id': u'116184195', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glennmr', u'text': u'There are several things wrong with the calc that are not really addressed by the author. I have looked at several sites that seem to think it is reasonable to replace all energy production from all sources with solar panels because of this calculation. It does not have proper caveats to show its limitations and that makes it just bogus since it is not even close to being feasible. 
The calc assumes full 1000 watt/m2 hitting the panels for 8 hours a day for 250 days out of the year. That power level is ideal at the equator at noon and not what happens even with tracking. Higher latitudes will obviously have less insolation. Here is a calculator if you want to look such:
http://www.pveducation.org/pvcdrom/properties-of-sunlight/calculation-of-solar-insolation
Of course, there are issues such as the energy coming out of the panels is not instantaneously useable everywhere to do anything without conversion losses and doesn’t even include inverters. The 16 hours a day when energy is not available and therefore would require storage--which is really not at all plausible due to the limits of such is not even mentioned. Anyone that thinks energy storage is easy and is going to get cheap is wrong—batteries, compressed air, molten salts, gravity storage…etc. are all very expensive, very low energy density and net negative energy systems. There is nothing mentioned about conversion efficiency or transportation…etc. 
And these OK to leave out of the calc, but must be included to show limitations. I did one similar for nuclear power—about 13000 to 15000 nuclear plants could provide about 500 quads of energy…and that is not really feasible. (whenever I post such things, many people seem to retreat to ideological positions rather than actually looking at the calcs.)', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527082695000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'this calculation', u'effect': u'to replace all energy production from all sources with solar panels'}, {u'cause': u'the limits of such', u'effect': u'which is really not at all plausible'}], u'author_id': u'17680035', u'in_reply_to': u'116133266', u'id': u'116138367', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Mazter', u'text': u'BQSTART

Evaluated against these objective criteria, none of the 24 studies provides convincing evidence that these basic feasibility criteria can be met. Of a maximum possible unweighted feasibility score of seven, the highest score for any one study was four. Eight of 24 scenarios (33%) provided no form of system simulation. Twelve (50%) relied on unrealistic forecasts of energy demand. While four studies (17%; all regional) articulated transmission requirements, only two scenarios—drawn from the same study—addressed ancillary-service requirements. In addition to feasibility issues, the heavy reliance on exploitation of hydroelectricity and biomass raises concerns regarding environmental sustainability and social justice. Strong empirical evidence of feasibility must be demonstrated for any study that attempts to construct or model a low-carbon energy future based on any combination of low-carbon technology.
BQEND
So pedantically they perhaps did not say 100% was impossible- just that the meta study revealed to them - with their distinct criteria - that these studies were flawed.

Can we- the UK do it? If we had 30 years of investment in building standards, heat pumps, public transport, EVs and offshore wind and new pumped air/hydro [which means would have to convert Welsh and Scottish reservoirs to twin lake pumped hydro] then may be. But we would also need to import French nuclear, Spanish solar etc as well [but export wind].

Now, back to reality, if you take a look at PVGIS you will see that 1,000kWh/kWp is certainly possible for a lot of the UK for south facing panels. 1kWp of panels at 20% efficiency would be approx 4.8m2, so about 208kWh's/m2.
I believe I gave a similar figure earlier. I also explained that generation of twice this is possible in sunnier areas, and that further gains can be made with single or dual axis systems.
So is 400kWh's/m2 reasonable, certainly looks so.

description: Dana Nuccitelli: Republicans paid by the fossil fuel industry deny these realities
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Dana Nuccitelli: Republicans paid by the fossil fuel industry deny these realities
og_fields.og:title: Yes, EVs are green and global warming is raising sea levels | Dana Nuccitelli
text:
Last week, the House Science, Space and Technology Committee held yet another climate science hearing similar to those from April 2017, February 2017, January 2016, May 2015, June 2014, December 2013, and so on. It seems as though disputing established climate science is House Republicans’ favorite hobby. This time, it was Philip Duffy’s turn to spend two hours playing whack-a-mole with the committee Republicans’ endless supply of long-debunked climate myths.
Rep. Mo Brooks (R-AL) claimed that sea level rise is due to the White Cliffs of Dover tumbling into the ocean (yes, really), and his colleagues argued that scientists in the 1970s were predicting global cooling, that Earth is just returning to its “normal temperature,” that Antarctic ice is growing, and sea levels are hardly rising. 
Nice rejoinder to yesterday's silliness about rocks (and not melting ice) raising sea-level. You need an 8 mile diameter, 6 quadrillion pound rock (every year) to reproduce the observed sea-level rise. that's a really big rock! https://t.co/MQgTaYpdlq https://t.co/N8kmIgBDLh
Those last two claims originated from a Wall Street Journal (WSJ) editorial entered into the Congressional record by Chairman Lamar Smith (R-TX), written by Fred Singer. As the group Ozone Action documented, Singer has been a lifetime contrarian on virtually every scientific subject imaginable - acid rain, nuclear winter, nuclear waste, nuclear war, ozone depletion, secondhand smoke, amphibian population loss, and even minimum wage benefits. In recent decades he’s worked for a plethora of fossil fuel-funded think tanks, denying established climate science.
Singer’s WSJ editorial is difficult to follow, largely because it contradicts itself several times, saying:
there is also good data showing sea levels are in fact rising at an accelerating rate ... to keep the rate of rise constant, as observed...
Obviously if sea level rise is accelerating, it’s not increasing at a constant rate. The WSJ later “corrected” that first sentence, thus removing one of the few accurate statements in the editorial - sea level rise is indeed accelerating.
The article has been updated from “data showing sea levels are in fact rising at an accelerating rate” to “in fact rising at a constant rate”which doesn’t make it more correct.@WSJopinion @jamestaranto why the quiet update? pic.twitter.com/l9IftFNpSB
Singer’s explanation for why the accelerating sea level rise isn’t accelerating likewise contradicts itself:
the temperature of sea water has no direct effect on sea-level rise … accumulation of ice on the Antarctic continent has been offsetting the steric effect [sea level rise due to warming temperatures] for at least several centuries.
Here, Singer first claims that the basic physics of thermal expansion is wrong, or at least somehow doesn’t apply to ocean water, but then argues it is real and is merely being offset by ice growth on Antarctica. The latter claim is of course also wrong – Antarctica has been losing land ice and a recent study found that it’s responsible for 8% of sea level rise since 1993 (thermal expansion is the biggest contributor, at 42%). 
As one sea level researcher at Climate Feedback described Singer’s editorial, “If this were an essay in one of my undergraduate classes, he would fail.” The whole thing is complete nonsense, denying basic physics, and yet was published in the WSJ and entered into the congressional record. This is the material that House Republicans and their conservative media allies who reject climate science and oppose all climate policies find most compelling. That says a lot about the state of climate denial on the American right today.
Latest #WallStreetJournal op-ed "The Sea Is Rising, but Not Because of Climate Change".Stay tuned for these great followup @WSJ op-eds:"Objects are falling, but Not Because of Gravity""Continents are moving, but Not Because of Plate Tectonics"..https://t.co/GW7NHaZamT
Around the same time, Politico ran a story written by Jonathan Lesser, who’s an energy industry consultant with the Koch-, Mercer-, tobacco industry-, and Exxon-funded Manhattan Institute (which Politico failed to mention). It claims, based on a Manhattan Institute report written by Lesser, that “more electric cars and trucks will mean more pollution.”
This conclusion rests upon a number of shaky assumptions. First, it considers not today’s power grid mix, but rather the US Energy Information Administration (EIA)’s projections out to the year 2050. The EIA is notorious for underestimating the growth of clean energy, and projects that coal will continue to supply 22% of US electricity 32 years hence. To put this in perspective, the share of US electricity supplied by coal fell from 51% in 2008 to 31% in 2016. According to an analysis by the Union of Concerned Scientists, nearly half of the remaining coal plants will likely retire or convert to natural gas in the near future. In short, the EIA is unrealistically bullish on fossil fuels.
Electricity generated by burning coal produces significant air pollution, and so using these assumptions, Lesser concludes that American electric cars will generate more air pollutants that are harmful to human health than gasoline-powered cars. But if the electricity generated to charge electric vehicles is cleaner than in his assumptions – a near-certainty – the conclusions won’t hold.
Lesser also admits that even with these conservative assumptions, carbon pollution emissions from electric cars would be at least 70% lower in 2050 than those from gasoline-powered cars. He dismisses this result by claiming “the [carbon pollution] reductions will have no impact on climate” (because it’s a small change relative to the carbon pollution from all American power generation), but this argument could apply to any individual effort to cut carbon pollution (it’s called a ‘Tragedy of the Commons’). In fact, transportation currently accounts for close to 30% of US carbon pollution, so switching to electric cars is a critically important step to tackle America’s large contribution to climate change.
The cleanliness of an electric car depends on the source of its electricity, and that varies greatly by region. The Union of Concerned Scientists created an interactive tool to check this based on US zip code. Currently, half of American electric cars are sold in California, where in many areas they achieve an equivalent of 130 miles per gallon. And about one-third of households buying electric cars today also have solar panels to charge them, producing zero-pollution fuel.
In short, yes, electric cars are green and global warming is causing sea level rise. It’s not a coincidence that arguments to the contrary are made by individuals whose paychecks and campaign donations are supplied by the fossil fuel industry.

description: Charity says at least 65 people have died in Pakistani city as temperatures exceed 40C
headline: m
og_fields.og:description: Charity says at least 65 people have died in Pakistani city as temperatures exceed 40C
og_fields.og:title: Death toll climbs in Karachi heatwave
text:
An intense heatwave across south Asia has killed dozens of people with sustained temperatures in excess of 40C (104F) coinciding with power cuts and Ramadan, when many Muslims avoid eating or drinking water.
At least 65 people have died in Karachi in recent days according to the charitable organisation that runs the central morgue in the Pakistani port city, as volunteers handed out water to labourers and others working outside in temperatures as high as 44C.
Local media reports claimed the death toll could have exceeded 100 in the sprawling megacity of 15 million, where high temperatures are exacerbated by an absence of green space, estimated to make up just 7% of the urban area.
Authorities in Karachi have not confirmed the death toll but urged people to stay indoors and keep drinking water.
Parts of the city have also been suffering from power cuts, particularly early in the morning when more people than usual have been waking to eat before sunrise in line with Ramadan fasting rituals.
During the annual month-long rite, Muslims refrain from eating or drinking anything including water between sunrise and sunset, though children, older people, the sick and pregnant women usually do not participate.
The Edhi Foundation, which runs Karachi’s central morgue, said most of the dead in the city were working-class people from poorer neighbourhoods, including children and elderly people.
“They work around heaters and boilers in textile factories and there is eight to nine hours of [scheduled power outages] in these areas,” Faisal Edhi, the head of the foundation, told Reuters.
Fazlullah Pechuho, the health minister of Sindh province, denied that anyone had died, however, telling the Dawn newspaper: “I categorically reject that people have died due to heatstroke in Karachi.”
A heatwave in 2015 left morgues and hospitals overwhelmed and killed at least 1,200 mostly elderly, sick, and homeless people.
In 2015, the Edhi morgue ran out of freezer space after about 650 bodies were brought in the space of a few days. Ambulances left decaying corpses outside in the sweltering heat.
Extreme temperatures were also recorded in neighbouring India, with parts of Maharashtra state reaching 47C on Monday.
More than 22,000 people died in heatwaves in India between 1992 and 2005, according to government data released last year.
Authorities say that figure has fallen dramatically since as a result of public health campaigns, including training medical staff to diagnose heat-related illnesses and sending colour-coded temperature warnings through the media and WhatsApp.
Last year, about 222 Indians died because of the heat, the government says, down from 1,111 in 2016 and 2,040 the year before.
Temperatures in Karachi are expected to stay above 40C until 24 May, according to weather forecasters. High temperatures were also predicted to last another 48 hours in India.
Reuters contributed to this report

article_tags: [Climate change, Royal Dutch Shell, Oil, Oil and gas companies, Energy industry, Business, Environment, UK news]
description: Oil firm grilled over carbon emissions, but defeats motion calling for tougher targets
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Oil firm grilled over carbon emissions, but defeats motion calling for tougher targets
og_fields.og:title: Shell investors revolt over pay and maintain pressure over climate change
text:
Shell investors have rebelled over the company’s executive pay, as the Anglo-Dutch oil company came under pressure to take stronger action on climate change.
While chief executive Ben van Beurden’s €8.9m (£7.79m) pay package for 2017 was approved, more than a quarter of shareholders voted against the firm’s remuneration report at its annual general meeting on Tuesday.
Gerard Kleisterlee, the chair of the remuneration committee, blamed the result on proxy advisers.
Influential shareholder adviser ISS had urged investors to reject the pay award because of the company’s performance on sustainable development targets and an accident in Pakistan which led to the deaths of 221 people. 
The rebellion is the latest in a series of revolts against corporate pay, including 37% of shareholders voting against or abstaining on AstroZenca’s remuneration report last week. Melrose, Inmarsat and Unilever have been hit this year with significant votes against pay packages, though Shell’s fellow oil major BP avoided one on Monday.
Shell also faced a grilling from investors over how sincere its action is on reducing carbon emissions, with about half the questions related to climate change during the four-hour AGM. 
However, the company defeated a resolution calling for it to set tougher emissions targets in line with the Paris climate deal. 
The resolution was backed by 5.54% of shareholders; a similar resolution in 2017 was backed by 6.3%. 
“Investors are sending a clear signal to Shell and all oil and gas companies, that they will not accept a goal of halving net carbon emissions by 2050 [set by Shell],” said Mark van Baal of Follow This, the group which brought the proposal. 
He noted that seven of the Netherland’s 10 biggest asset owners had supported the resolution.
Van Beurden repeatedly defended the company’s record on climate change, referring to its target to halve the carbon footprint of its products by 2050 and company scenarios showing how the world could keep temperatures below 2C.
“This ambition is truly industry-leading, nobody else comes close. It is seriously ambitious,” he told the AGM, adding that the resolution would tie the firm’s hands.
“Your company wants to lead, so let us. So follow us,” he quipped in reference to the activist shareholder group’s name.
Van Baal accused the chief executive of misleading investors that Shell’s carbon targets were aligned with a sub-2C world. “I’m not misleading shareholders,” van Beurden retorted.
The chief executive said that at some point the firm would have to grapple with how to tie its carbon targets to executive pay, without giving a timeframe for action. 
The company also faced questions over the impact of its operations in Argentina, Nigeria and the Netherlands, conditions and terms for workers, and an ongoing corruption trial in Italy.

I have long felt that people keeping pets (for the person's comfort & enjoyment) plays out very much like slavery.
BQEND
We don't all have that kind of relationship with our animal friends. It is true the majority of people see their "pets" as property, many "train" them to act like compliant robots.
My relationship with my avatar is one of mutual respect. Our relationship isnt based on dominance, he is free to go in & out & pretty much allowed to do as his nature dictates. Because of society's rules & laws & modern life, there are certain things I must protect him & them against. He knows a few terms NO, Come, Leave.
I once watched a typical dog owner with 2 Labradors, they came to his recall instantly, sat on command offered each paw in turn when prompted to have their paws wiped clean with a towel, before leaping into their respective cages in the back of the estate car they came in. I was absolutely appalled at this demonstration.
I wouldn't accept the responsibility of being my best friends guardian if i couldn't give him 24/7 of my time or provide him the freedom he has, we share everything we do & i try my hardest to treat him equally to the horror of many people. As i say there are a few things Human society frowns upon that i have to stop him doing for his own safety, i only wish i didn't. 
But our relationship is based on trust & love & as such i trust him with my life, he treats me with the upmost respect & affection he has never shown any form of aggression towards me or anyone else!', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527299228000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17206208', u'in_reply_to': u'116183762', u'id': u'116241401', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'VinceDaFox', u'text': u'BQSTART

From a sampling of the Guardian's own material, these links:
https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/apr/26/were-doomed-mayer-hillman-on-the-climate-reality-no-one-else-will-dare-mention
https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/may/21/human-race-just-001-of-all-life-but-has-destroyed-over-80-of-wild-mammals-study
https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/oct/21/insects-giant-ecosystem-collapsing-human-activity-catastrophe
https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/may/01/melbournes-water-supply-at-risk-due-to-collapse-of-forests-caused-by-logging
https://www.theguardian.com/environment/planet-oz/2018/apr/05/you-dont-have-to-be-a-climate-science-denier-to-join-the-monash-coal-forum-but-it-helps
https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/jul/10/earths-sixth-mass-extinction-event-already-underway-scientists-warn
https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/apr/27/last-chance-to-study-and-name-australias-vanishing-species-scientists-warn-mps
And from David Goodall, who was recently in the news, a reflection similar to Mayer Hillman's:
https://thenewdaily.com.au/news/world/2018/05/14/david-goodall-future-humanity-doubts/
Make no mistake people, we've long passed the Rubicon. We have consigned a huge chuck of our biodiversity to inevitable and unavoidable extinction, and within the next century a serious chunk of humanity will follow. It's simple closed-systems equilibrium science, a fact of numbers and the laws of nature.
Societies and the people who govern them are kidding themselves that there's still a chance for a soft landing - if they're even facing the fact of collapse in the first place. There is no soft landing, there's only a hard one or a very hard one, with the choice of even harder still if we don't immediately enact emergency measures to slightly reduce the damage that's coming.
Anyone who says otherwise simply hasn't done the calculus or understood the processes involved.', u'recommendation_count': u'12', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527087766000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13633283', u'id': u'116141829', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RavefromDave', u'text': u'Nature is defending itself that's the problem. Anyway - why should we worry ourselves about the effect other countries' economies have on the planet? Because it's the planet. Would you drink out of a bucket of water that you, personally, haven't spat in?
There has to be some kind of balance between the demands made on developed countries and those made on developing countries, of course. Of course it's not just that we could, for example, pump tonnes of CO2 into the atmosphere as we built huge road and rail networks a century or more ago, and then demand that our former colonies catch up with us by laying their own roads using electric or solar powered steamrollers. But if you make it about tree cover - we've got lots, and it's increasing. It's what we do with redundant farmland, and how we decorate our suburbs. Did you know that London counts as a forest, due to the density of trees?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527086908000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the density of trees', u'effect': u'that london counts as a forest'}], u'author_id': u'1375646', u'in_reply_to': u'116125046', u'id': u'116141148', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Goradhaka', u'text': u'BQSTART
You've confused nature with individual organisms.
BQENDNo I haven’t. If individual organisms are a prodcut of nature, then so too is their concern.
BQSTART
Nature doesn't have concerns because it's not actually an entity.
BQENDThe body of nature is the universe, and nature is the sum total of everything in it. It has more of a right to call itself an entity than you do, since you are dependent on it, but nature is not dependent on you; you are a part of it, it is complete, with or without you. We are products of nature, so how can we be more than our source? “She walks an autumn ampler than the wind/ Cries up for us and colder than the frost/ Pricks in our spirits at the summer's end,/ And over the bare spaces of our skies/ She sees a barer sky that does not bend.”*
Furthermore, nature exists in consciousness, which is universal. Obviously. Where else would it exist, if not in consciousness, which operates on many levels, dreaming and waking being the most obvious example. Existence and consciousness are one and the same. An electron ‘knows’ that it's an electron, and what to do, otherwise it wouldn’t be able to do it, and you would have to invent an exterior knower which knows on its behalf - like God - which I suspect you would be reluctant to do, quite understandably. That leaves you an alternative. If it isn’t an external deity guiding the electron to behave according to nature’s laws, then it must be the electron. Nature ‘knows’ how to exist. It’s the ghost in the machine, if you like; the programme: "What talent for the makeshift thought/ A living corpus out of odds and ends?/ What pedagogic patience taught/ Preoccupied and savage elements/ To dance into a segregated charm?/ Who showed the whirlwind how to be an arm,/ And gardened from the wilderness of space/ The sensual properties of one dear face?”* 
Some people are so literal they can only see what they can see, and take that for reality, without acknowledging that what we see remains a mystery. The sky appears to bend because those are the limitations of our perspective, and those limitations operate at the highest level of inquiry. But the literal see a body that appears separate and end up assuming that they’re separate, independent entities, which leads to anthropocentrism. Anthropocentrism, which prioritises humans above all else in the universe, has brought us to the brink of disaster, so recommending it as the best argument for our environmental future appears problematic.
*WallaceStevens - ‘Anatomy of Monotony’ * W.H.Auden - ‘In Sickness And In Health’', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527177084000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"it 's not actually an entity", u'effect': u"bqstart nature does n't have concerns"}, {u'cause': u'those are the limitations of our perspective and those limitations operate at the highest level of inquiry', u'effect': u'the sky appears to bend'}, {u'cause': u'which', u'effect': u'anthropocentrism'}], u'author_id': u'100406231', u'in_reply_to': u'116132454', u'id': u'116186928', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Tylerolog', u'text': u'I have visited China and India. Not at the breakneck rate at which humans are killing species.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527141453000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4218756', u'in_reply_to': u'116159606', u'id': u'116161270', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'taneagrafika', u'text': u'No, they can't--and therefore shouldn't--have rights, because they are not legal persons and are incapable of being held responsible. But that doesn't mean we, who are legal persons, do not have the duty to protect them. But foolishly and needlessly casting the debate in the terms of rights just gives the whole debate a faint air of precious silliness.
In fact, the argument from self-interest is perfectly adequate for establishing our duty to preserve natural habitats. As the world dies, we die, it is just that simple. The reason we have historically been less than trusty stewards of the natural world is that we were ignorant of the many ways we depend on it and can suffer as a result of its degradation (plus the fact that humanity does not possess one undivided set of interests and therefore never acts in unison).
If we can't act when our natural habitat is dying, what makes you think we will act purely on the basis of some ceremonial "right" we assign to a plant? In other words, if the thing that is most important is still not important enough, why should something of marginal importance be enough?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527086385000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'they are not legal persons and are incapable of being held responsible', u'effect': u"therefore shouldn't have rights"}], u'author_id': u'2747600', u'id': u'116140749', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Michael J Ahles', u'text': u'What we do to nature we do to ourselves. Like it or not.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527140450000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100340837', u'in_reply_to': u'116153706', u'id': u'116160953', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'VoiceOreason', u'text': u'Just more evidence that western civilization is sliding into irrelevance.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527140298000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3855284', u'id': u'116160900', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Meghan Kathleen Jamieson', u'text': u'I think this is a complicated issue for a few reasons.One is that in parts of the world where people have fewer children, each child uses a lot more resources, and indeed people come to expect that level of consumption which is in itself totally unsustainable. One of the effects of having fewer kids, in practice, seems to be conditioning people to expect a higher standard of living. You can even see this effect somewhat among families with only a few kids as opposed to larger families - and not because people don't care, it just seems to be the effect on family lifestyle.The other element I think is that culturally and economically we don't really encourage moderation. We tend to think moderation in one area is unrelated to another, but I suspect that isn't the case. While some individuals are less inclined to certain types of excess, generally the ability to be moderate can be transferred to some extent to other areas of life, it's about habit building and learning how to manage your own behaviour. So can we really expect people who can't be moderate about consumer consumption to moderate their family size? Or to put it another way, if we keep encouraging people to consume immoderately, won't that effect things like family size?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527085529000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"not people do n't care", u'effect': u'it just seems to be the effect on family lifestyle'}], u'author_id': u'12202393', u'in_reply_to': u'116129030', u'id': u'116140077', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Marjakuusi', u'text': u'What has to happen is that the supposed representatives of the people have to use their power so ostentatiously bestowed upon them by the people, and actually take action that protects the general interests. If whale hunting was banned -and their extinction wasn't nowhere near the threat to land dwellers as global warming or deforestation are, I'm sure the rainforest can be protected, or at least exploited in way that is sustainable, like cut one, plant one, or hell, just grow forest for commercial purposes, as we do with farm animals or crops. State owned tree plantations on land sound pretty viable to maintain and exploit, specially when there is no shortage of barren swaths of land around the world that used be woodland', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527085029000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15024183', u'id': u'116139739', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ns124C41', u'text': u'Economics (a word itself derived from the Greek word for managing one’s affairs and related to the word ecology) has at best been aquasi-science, and at worst the ‘scientific’ basis for crackpot value systems that have used to justify idiotic social policies from trickle-down theory to Facism.
A pseudo-science that can label inconvenient realities as ‘externalities’ is not capable of describing reality at all and is not a science at all, but should be recognized as merely a system rationalizations, favoring the policies of one or another faction.
There have been numerous attempts to glue together an economic theory that not only addresses human transactions but attempts to assess the planetary costs of certain policy choices. So far as I know there has been no new Adam Smith who has been able to articulate how this can be done, and defines responsible economic behavior as as incorporating a synoptic, planetary view, not simply self interest.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527160162000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17587471', u'id': u'116175044', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'NinaBeckett', u'text': u'To evolve to that point, we would need at the minimum 100,000 years. In the absolute centre of that cosmology was Hell - Heaven was the outermost layer. Earth was just outside of Hell. The capacity for human-kind to screw nature is well integrated into that worldview, even foundational in some ways. u'author_id': u'18451441', u'in_reply_to': u'116160470', u'id': u'116169741', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PatriciaMF', u'text': u'Anyone who’s kept a dog, to give u'18451441', u'in_reply_to': u'116149741', u'id': u'116168796', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Steve Bennett', u'text': u'Law is an artificial concept created by man. It was founded on property rights. Those rights contain include definitions of property, rights to alter and rights of disposal.
The bedrock of modern capitalism is the law of contract. Without which our society could not function.
Within this construct nature has no rights. The law is used to restrict certain aspects of what a property owner can do with the property that s/he owns. And since property has none of the attributes of human beings, (a tree cannot contest a felling order), it cannot express individual will.
So, on one level the ideas advanced in this article are daft/borderline loony. But the continuation of our species is dependent upon us protecting the earths environment and all nature.
Evolution did not stop at the development of homo sapiens. And in that sense we are no different to previous species (long since extinct) that once upon a time strutted about the planet claiming to own it.
One can imagine the dinosaurs discussing ( I stretch the point here) answers to their plight around the time of their own extinction as a species. ' Look, some of us are 100 feet long with a brain the size of a walnut!'. These guys eat a forest for breakfast!
Well of course that meeting never took place, because dinosaurs were too undeveloped to understand what was happening to themselves as a species.
And we are developed enough too. We use artificial constraints (an economic, political and legal system) which frustrates any attempt to put nature in front of the drive to amass vast profit for a few at the expense of nature which of course we are but a small segment.
And since we rely upon our environment for our survival, then I would say that the artificial systems we have created ignore natural laws of existence. Of course, this could all be changed, but not under the present order of human society.
So unless change in human society happens we will go the way of the dinosaurs. 100 feet tall with brains the size of walnuts.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527137839000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'dinosaurs were too undeveloped to understand what was happening to themselves as a species', u'effect': u'well of course that meeting never took place'}], u'author_id': u'15246253', u'id': u'116160258', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'mtn74', u'text': u'i have to agree...rights based philosophy for getting people to do their part in society and for the planet is completely useless, people inevitably put their "rights" before all else, be that forests, eating junk food, developing diabetes, driving around in cars. description: For decades our laws have been a licence to destroy the environment. Now, from the Amazon to Australia, the tide is turning, says the campaigner Mari Margil
og_fields.og:description: For decades our laws have been a licence to destroy the environment. Now, from the Amazon to Australia, the tide is turning, says the campaigner Mari Margil
og_fields.og:title: Our laws make slaves of nature. It’s not just humans who need rights | Mari Margil
text:
The Amazon rainforest is often called the earth’s lungs, and generates 20% of the world’s oxygen. Yet in the past half-century nearly a fifth of it has been cut down. The felling and burning of millions of trees is releasing massive amounts of carbon, in turn depleting the Amazon’s capacity to be one of the world’s largest carbon sinks – the natural systems that suck up and store carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.
Recently, 25 children brought a lawsuit to end the deforestation and its devastating impacts on the environment and their own wellbeing. The case made its way to Colombia’s supreme court, which issued its decision last month. While deforestation is hardly a new issue in this region, the court’s response to the lawsuit certainly was. Commenting that environmental degradation – not only in the Amazon but worldwide – is so significant that it threatens “human existence”, the court declared the Colombian Amazon a “subject of rights”.
In 1972 the law professor Christopher Stone published a seminal article, Should Trees Have Standing?, that explored the possibility of recognising the legal rights of nature. He described how women and slaves had long been treated as rightless in law, and suggested that just as they had eventually attained rights, so trees and other nonhuman living things should also do so.
Today, environmental laws regulate the human use and destruction of nature. They legalise fracking, drilling, and even dynamiting the tops off mountains to mine coal. The consequences are proving catastrophic: the die-off crisis of the world’s coral reefs, accelerating species extinction, climate change. Finally, though, this is changing. In 2006 the first law recognising the legal rights of nature was enacted in the borough of Tamaqua, Pennsylvania, in the United States. The community sought to prevent dredging sludge laden with PCBs (polychlorinated biphenyl) being dumped in an abandoned coalmine. The organisation I work for, the Community Environmental Legal Defense Fund, helped the council draft the law, transforming nature from being rightless to possessing rights to exist and flourish. It was the first such law in the world. Communities across more than 10 US states have now followed suit, including New Hampshire, Colorado and Pittsburgh.
After the decision to grant legal rights to nature in Pennsylvania, representatives of my organisation met Ecuador’s constituent assembly in 2008, which was elected to draft a new constitution. We discussed the rights of nature, and why communities all over the world find themselves unable to protect nature under laws that authorise its exploitation. The assembly’s president, Alberto Acosta, told us: “Nature is a slave.”
In 2006 the first law recognising the legal rights of nature was enacted in the borough of Tamaqua, Pennsylvania
However, that year Ecuador enshrined the rights of nature – or Pachamama (Mother Earth) – in its constitution, the first country to do so. Since then Bolivia has put in place a Law of Mother Earth. Courts in India and Colombia have similarly ruled that ecosystems possess rights. In Mexico, Pakistan, Australia and other countries, rights-of-nature frameworks are being proposed and enacted.
Colombia’s supreme court was asked to consider the climate-change impacts of Amazon deforestation in the lawsuit that led to its groundbreaking ruling. Similarly, in Nepal the Center for Economic and Social Development is working to advance rights to protect against climate change. The Himalayas – known as the world’s third pole – are experiencing warming faster than any other mountain range on earth. With the melting of ice and snow, a Sherpa told us, “the mountains are turning black”. But now a constitutional amendment has been developed that would, if adopted, recognise the rights of the Himalayas to a climate system free from global-warming pollution. It would for the first time provide a platform for Nepal to hold major climate polluters accountable for violating the rights of the mountains.
Law today divides the world into two categories: persons, capable of having rights; and property, unable to possess rights. While there is no universally agreed upon definition of “legal person”, it is generally understood to mean an entity capable of bearing rights and duties. The problem that the rights-of-nature movement is now encountering is that this definition is predictably problematic when it comes to rivers, forests or nature more broadly.
In 2017, for example, the state high court in Uttarakhand, India, ruled that in order to protect the Ganges and Yamuna rivers, they should be considered legal persons with “all corresponding rights, duties and liabilities of a living person”. In a subsequent appeal to India’s supreme court, the state government asked whether, if the rivers flood, leading to the death of a human being, a lawsuit could be filed for damages. Could the Uttarakhand chief secretary of state, named by the court as one of several officials in loco parentis, be held liable on the river’s behalf? In this case, the supreme court decided not.
Can we hold a river accountable for flooding, or a forest for burning? Of course not. Yet existing legal systems force us to think of nature in terms of human concerns rather than what concerns nature. With the past three years the warmest in recorded history, and as we face what has been called the sixth great extinction, lawmakers and judges appear increasingly to agree that it is time to secure the highest form of legal protection for nature, through the recognition of rights.
To make progress in this area, we must break away from legal strictures that were never intended to apply to nature, such as legal personhood, and establish a new structure that addresses what nature needs. Perhaps we can call this framework legal naturehood. A recent symposium at Tulane Law School, in New Orleans, brought together academics, lawyers and activists to develop a set of guidelines for recognising and enforcing legal rights of nature, known as the rights-of-nature principles.
These define the basic rights that nature needs, including rights to existence, regeneration and restoration. Further, they call for monetary damages derived from violations of these rights to be used solely to protect and restore nature to its pre-damaged state. In addition, they outline a means for nature to defend its own rights – like children unable to speak for themselves in court – by being the named “real party in interest” in administrative and court proceedings. The principles build on laws and judicial decisions that have begun to accumulate in this new area of law, laying the groundwork for what legal naturehood could look like.
As daily headlines tell us how we are tearing holes in the very fabric of life on earth, it is time to make a fundamental shift in how we govern ourselves towards nature – before, as Colombia’s constitutional court wrote, it’s too late.
• Mari Margil is associate director of the US-based Community Environmental Legal Defense Fund

description: Litigants from eight countries claim EU institutions are not protecting fundamental rights
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Litigants from eight countries claim EU institutions are not protecting fundamental rights
og_fields.og:title: 'We can't see a future': group takes EU to court over climate change
text:
Lawyers acting for a group including a French lavender farmer and members of the indigenous Sami community in Sweden have launched legal action against the EU’s institutions for failing to adequately protect them against climate change.
A case is being pursued in the Luxembourg-based general court, Europe’s second highest, against the European parliament and the council of the European Union for allowing overly high greenhouse gas emissions to continue until 2030.
The families, including young children, claim their lives have been blighted by the policy decisions in Brussels, and that the EU’s inadequate emissions targets will cause more suffering.
The legal complaint asserts that the EU’s existing climate target to reduce domestic greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% by 2030, compared with 1990 levels, does not protect their fundamental rights of life, health, occupation and property.
The litigants, from Portugal, Germany, France, Italy, Romania, Kenya, Fiji, and the Swedish Sami Youth Association Sáminuorra, say the EU should define a higher reduction target.
The claim specifically targets the EU’s emission trading scheme directive, the effort sharing regulation and the land use, land use change and forestry regulation.
The plaintiffs, who are not seeking compensation for their loss, are asking the court to declare the three acts null and void, “since they violate the plaintiff’s rights and are not in line with higher ranking law”.
According to a legal summary of the complaint, to avoid a vacuum, the court will be asked to keep the acts in force until a stronger version of them has been enacted. Lawyers claim there is a case for this in article 263 of the treaty on the functioning of the EU.
In 2015, a court in The Hague ordered the Dutch government to cut its emissions by at least 25% within five years, ruling that its plans to cut emissions by 14-17% compared with 1990 levels by 2020 were unlawful, given the scale of the threat posed by climate change. The government has appealed the decision, which will be heard in The Hague on Monday.
Maurice Feschet, 72, a lavender farmer in Grignan, Provence, told the Guardianhe became involved in the action against the EU after losing 44% of his harvest in six years because of climate change.
He said: “My family has been farming here since the 1800s. I am taking this action for my 38-year-old son who lives on the farm. We want him to continue to be able to farm, but it is not going to be easy. There must be more done.”
Alfredo Sendim, 52, an organic farmer in central Portugal, said the irregularity of the climate in his area raised serious doubts about the long-term sustainability of his business. He said: “Last year we had almost the entire year without a drop of rain. Then we had two weeks and all the rain that we should have had fell.”
In Sweden, the traditional Sami way of life herding reindeer is said to be under pressure from rising temperatures that threaten the size of herds. Warmer winters mean less snow and more rain freezing into ice, making it harder for the animals to reach the plants they need to eat. 
Sanna Vannar, 22, the chair of Sáminuorra, said: “If we lose the reindeers, the Sami culture will be lost. Many of the Sami youth want to stay with their families and be reindeer herders, but they cannot see a future. This is mostly due to the threat of climate change. This must be urgently addressed for the safety of our generation and the next generations.”
Roda Verheyen, the lawyer acting on behalf of the families, said: “Climate change is already an issue for the courts in the European countries and around the world.
“The plaintiff families are putting their trust in the EU courts and legal system to protect their fundamental rights of life, health, occupation and property which are under threat of climate change. The EU courts must now listen to these families and ensure that they are protected.”
Scientists from the thinktank Climate Analytics are providing expert evidence to the families’ lawyers. The German non-governmental organisation Protect the Planet is bearing all the costs related to the legal case.
Climate Action Network (CAN), Europe’s largest NGO working on climate and energy issues, is also supporting the action.
Wendel Trio, CAN’s director in Europe, said: “This is part of a strategy to get the EU institutions to increase their targets. In 2015, as part of the Paris agreement, countries agreed to pursue efforts to limit temperature rise to 1.5°C.
“Yet, it is clear that the existing EU 2030 climate target is not enough to respect the commitments taken in the Paris agreement and should be increased. The EU needs under the agreement to confirm its target by 2020. This legal action initiated by normal families impacted by climate change is underlining the urgency and the necessity to increase it.”

They are ideologically opposed and no argument will have the slightest effect. The consequences of climate change are upon us. They will be forced to concede by the brutal facts.
It is true that population is the prime issue. It is behind these other things. It's the elephant in the room. Australia has got too big...that's visible in the state of our environment. But other parts of the world have grown by astonishing degrees.
The population crunch will come. It's too late to avert it. Let's not make it worse! 
I would suggest fines and punishment for having too many kids and the loss of benefits. I would suggest protecting the natural world by force. The situation is absolutely critical. It didn't have to be this way, but since the war our global population had grown to unsustainable levels.
Spare a thought for the frogs, birds, wild animals and forests. The rivers. We are destroying them and bow there is little left.
The positive here is that we are discussing this rather controversial issue. And doing so reasonably. It's time we acted to clean up our act and it's time our population came down dramatically.
The crunch is coming...indeed it is very close. War, poverty, starvation and disease will follow. Mass migration. Terrible scenes. It will be appalling. Perhaps had we acted decisively much earlier er might have averted this coming crisis.
It can't be all that far off. Human population growth is exponential and the shrinkage of the planets resource base is falling exponentially. Water, food, materials. It's bad. Malthus was right. We found ways to kick the can down the road...but the road does end.
To all who replied I'd like to say thanks for your civil tone. It's challenging stuff, and I take no delight in it. But we have to talk about population...with honesty and fearlessness. Hard as it is.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527666082000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16468522', u'in_reply_to': u'116393065', u'id': u'116396773', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Anthonyhu', u'text': u'BQSTART

BQEND
It isn't 
At least not before it is way to late to deal with climate change which in case you missed it is the topic
We are on course to hit a peak of between 9.5 and 10 billion by mid century (some say 11) and besides wishing up a plague again you have no solution. Denying aid to other countries (strange you are not demanding funding cuts to healthcare here) won't do it however much you'd like to inflict unnecessary suffering on those who are having the least impact. Better medical care and a reduction in infant mortality actually leads to lower not higher fertility rates but either way the size and the timing of the coming peak will not be significantly affected.
I'm glad you at least concede that the priority is to reduce the impact we have (you should always lead with that!). Bleating on endlessly about how many of us there are without the slightest idea of how a timely reduction could be achieved just undermines the simple steps that are absolutely possible and further enables those that are still intent on sabotaging action on sustainability in all areas.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527654536000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3333597', u'in_reply_to': u'116392262', u'id': u'116393065', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Guy Littleford', u'text': u'I fear you misunderstand me in this. I say clearly that we must act urgently to reduce our individual ecological footprint...all of us everywhere. And now! 
As for population reduction. It is going to happen. We need to stop interfering in this necessary natural process. that means that efforts to supply aid to areas in which population levels exceed the carrying capacity of the area. Bob Gelded was mistaken in his well intentioned efforts in Ethiopia. he solved nothing and only made the problem worse.
I do not suggest we carry on asked are because there is nothing we can do...not at all. I do suggest we stop resisting the inevitable reduction in numbers. What good does it achieve to rid certain parts of the world of malaria, dysentery, cholera and high infant mortality only to see the human population explode and engage in wars over dwindling resources.
Humans are not sacred. 
I would urge you to look at the facts concerning the decimation of the wilderness that supports the wider ecosystem. That is what needs urgent protection. Not the human race. 
The actions we take ourselves to reduce our impact are essential and vital. And we must stop the rape of the Amazon Basin, the African Wilderness, the Asian reefs and forests. Will people suffer? Certainly. That is unavoidable.
When the population us substantially reduced, assuming the planet is not damaged beyond repair by that point, it will be possible to improve human development while not ravaging the earth.
We have a choice. And no choice. Destroying the ecosystem, as we are doing, will come back to bite us. Already is.
My preference would be for a plague to strike that eliminates the bulk of the human population. If I get nailed, too bad. We are not that important as individuals.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527650832000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'there is nothing we can do not at all', u'effect': u'are'}], u'author_id': u'16468522', u'in_reply_to': u'116392006', u'id': u'116392262', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID9766495', u'text': u'So let's be clear.
1. You are apparently going to continue to claim dramatic population reduction is essential without feeling the slightest need to explain how this can (or can't) be achieved.
2. Your claim suggests that you don't see any point in efforts by individuals or governments to reduce the impact that we have on the environment - after all, what's the point? - according to you 'we have exceeded our carrying capacity' so until we deal with that we are doomed ... right?
3. As much as you may hate to admit it, deniers and those that suggest we continue much as we are, be that based on ideology, short term economics or plain ignorance LOVE your contribution because it helps them achieve exactly what they want.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527649605000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it helps them achieve exactly what they want', u'effect': u'that based on ideology love your contribution'}], u'author_id': u'3333597', u'in_reply_to': u'116391539', u'id': u'116392006', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Guy Littleford', u'text': u'It's not at all a question of ideology. Nor is it a question of the form of genocide I prefer. The hard fact is that the planet has a finite carrying capacity, and this is well exceeded. The terrible consequences are now being seen.
My personal preferences have.nothing to do with it.
Still, I think Bill Gates is misguided in spending vast resources.on things that only promote human population growth. Nature must take its course, and it will. Whatever we would prefer.
It's horrible and appalling I know. But so is the destruction of the.natural world we cause by our ludicrous numbers', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527647172000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'we', u'effect': None}], u'author_id': u'16468522', u'in_reply_to': u'116391015', u'id': u'116391539', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID9766495', u'text': u'I said nothing about your ideology but I'd be interested in what form of genocide you favor to quickly, not just slow population growth, but significantly reduce population in the time we have available. Progress is being made, but ultimately numbers have to come down very dramatically. It would be incorrect for.you to view my opinion as being ideological. I'm simply looking at the facts and have the reckless ability to say what is controversial, but utterly obvious.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527642468000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16468522', u'in_reply_to': u'116390221', u'id': u'116390500', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Ross Dudgeon', u'text': u'With .3% of the world's population and 1.8% of global emissions we produce 6 times the emissions per head of population than we should so any efforts we make to reduce this should be a priority even if we are a small player compared to the likes of China or America.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527641523000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12600370', u'in_reply_to': u'116349827', u'id': u'116390249', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID9766495', u'text': u'Australia and the world generally is under great stress because of the way we act while we are here. I'm not saying you are a denier but this is the latest denier/'do nothing, it's hopeless' meme and needs to be addressed head on just like all the rest.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527641411000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the way we act while we are here', u'effect': u'australia and the world generally is under great stress'}], u'author_id': u'3333597', u'in_reply_to': u'116389984', u'id': u'116390221', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Ross Dudgeon', u'text': u'You mean..... Of course, India and China may on a per capita basis produce lead pollution and emissions. Nevertheless, their numbers are so much greater, and so their planetary impact reflects that.
The problem has two factors. Consumption and numbers.
We could return to a primitive style of life and the planet could support greater numbers. Attenborough reports that at 6 billion that's the style of life in Uganda.
The Indians and Chinese are catching up with us per capita too.
The one child policy has averted a total population cataclysmic in China, although the situation is very far from ideal. 
We need a virus or something as effective to sweep the planet that will very dramatically reduce the human population of the planet if we are to avoid the calamity that approaches. 
You probably don't want to hear that. 
Well, the present rate of growth of the human population is totally unsustainable, and the number of humans makes us a scourge upon the planet.
And it's not just about atmospheric emissions...pollution, plastic in the oceans, pesticides, chemicals etc.
The last thing Africa needs is a cure for AIDS. And look at Bangladesh...what a disaster! Indonesia...bloody hell! 
This ends in conflict, mass migration and starvation. And devastation for the forests, rivers, lakes, seas, fish and wildlife. Humans and their farm animals now comprise 96 percent of mammalian life on earth. Only 4 percent is wild. 
And on a personal level I'm outraged. Why can't these idiots maintain control of their populations! The time to re-survey and sell this excess land is certainly well overduegiven the days of medium to long distance droving are over, althoughat times of drought running the "long paddock" is still used. A figure I saw outlined that Australia'sroad reserves approx. = the surface area of the Netherlands !
On the issue of farmers starting uncontrolled fires, especially via stubbleburns, all that I can tell you is that in my fire district (covering west centralVictoria) this is extremely rare. The season for doing stubble burns isstrictly controlled and aligns with local fire risks (our cockys couldn'tget a permit between Nov. 2017 and May 2018...very late) as assessedby local Govt. and the Fire Service. Given around 30% of grass fires are started by human activities and farmers are those that mainly live in those areas, they are certainly responsible for their share of uncontrolledfires (they are also the main people that fight them !).....in our district the majority of grass/bush fires attributed to human causation are stillpredominantly due to townies and road users (which can include farmers).
